Text:
He returned to America in 1912 because of one of his grandfather's
sudden illnesses, and after an excessively tiresome talk with the
perpetually convalescent old man he decided to put off until his
grandfather's death the idea of living permanently abroad.
Label: f

Text:
After a
prolonged search he took an apartment on Fifty-second Street and to all
appearances settled down.
Label: f

Text:
In 1913 Anthony Patch's adjustment of himself to the universe was in
process of consummation.
Label: f

Text:
Physically, he had improved since his
undergraduate days--he was still too thin but his shoulders had widened
and his brunette face had lost the frightened look of his freshman year.
Label: f

Text:
He was secretly orderly and in person spick and span--his friends
declared that they had never seen his hair rumpled.
Label: f

Text:
His nose was too
sharp; his mouth was one of those unfortunate mirrors of mood inclined
to droop perceptibly in moments of unhappiness, but his blue eyes were
charming, whether alert with intelligence or half closed in an
expression of melancholy humor.
Label: f

Text:
One of those men devoid of the symmetry of feature essential to the
Aryan ideal, he was yet, here and there, considered handsome--moreover,
he was very clean, in appearance and in reality, with that especial
cleanness borrowed from beauty.
Label: f

Text:
THE REPROACHLESS APARTMENT

Fifth and Sixth Avenues, it seemed to Anthony, were the uprights of a
gigantic ladder stretching from Washington Square to Central Park.
Label: f

Text:
Coming up-town on top of a bus toward Fifty-second Street invariably
gave him the sensation of hoisting himself hand by hand on a series of
treacherous rungs, and when the bus jolted to a stop at his own rung he
found something akin to relief as he descended the reckless metal steps
to the sidewalk.
Label: f

Text:
After that, he had but to walk down Fifty-second Street half a block,
pass a stodgy family of brownstone houses--and then in a jiffy he was
under the high ceilings of his great front room.
Label: f

Text:
This was entirely
satisfactory.
Label: f

Text: Here, after all, life began.
Label: f

Text:
Here he slept, breakfasted,
read, and entertained.
Label: f

Text:
The house itself was of murky material, built in the late nineties; in
response to the steadily growing need of small apartments each floor had
been thoroughly remodelled and rented individually.
Label: f

Text:
Of the four
apartments Anthony's, on the second floor, was the most desirable.
Label: f

Text:
The front room had fine high ceilings and three large windows that
loomed down pleasantly upon Fifty-second Street.
Label: f

Text:
In its appointments it
escaped by a safe margin being of any particular period; it escaped
stiffness, stuffiness, bareness, and decadence.
Label: f

Text:
It smelt neither of
smoke nor of incense--it was tall and faintly blue.
Label: f

Text:
There was a deep
lounge of the softest brown leather with somnolence drifting about it
like a haze.
Label: f

Text:
There was a high screen of Chinese lacquer chiefly
concerned with geometrical fishermen and huntsmen in black and gold;
this made a corner alcove for a voluminous chair guarded by an
orange-colored standing lamp.
Label: f

Text:
Deep in the fireplace a quartered shield
was burned to a murky black.
Label: f

Text:
Passing through the dining-room, which, as Anthony took only breakfast
at home, was merely a magnificent potentiality, and down a comparatively
long hall, one came to the heart and core of the apartment--Anthony's
bedroom and bath.
Label: f

Text: Both of them were immense.
Label: f

Text:
Under the ceilings of the former even the
great canopied bed seemed of only average size.
Label: f

Text:
On the floor an exotic
rug of crimson velvet was soft as fleece on his bare feet.
Label: f

Text:
His bathroom,
in contrast to the rather portentous character of his bedroom, was gay,
bright, extremely habitable and even faintly facetious.
Label: f

Text:
Framed around
the walls were photographs of four celebrated thespian beauties of the
day: Julia Sanderson as "The Sunshine Girl," Ina Claire as "The Quaker
Girl," Billie Burke as "The Mind-the-Paint Girl," and Hazel Dawn as "The
Pink Lady."
Label: f

Text:
Between Billie Burke and Hazel Dawn hung a print
representing a great stretch of snow presided over by a cold and
formidable sun--this, claimed Anthony, symbolized the cold shower.
Label: f

Text: The bathtub, equipped with an ingenious bookholder, was low and large.
Label: f

Text:
Beside it a wall wardrobe bulged with sufficient linen for three men and
with a generation of neckties.
Label: f

Text:
There was no skimpy glorified towel of a
carpet--instead, a rich rug, like the one in his bedroom a miracle of
softness, that seemed almost to massage the wet foot emerging from
the tub....

All in all a room to conjure with--it was easy to see that Anthony
dressed there, arranged his immaculate hair there, in fact did
everything but sleep and eat there.
Label: f

Text: It was his pride, this bathroom.
Label: f

Text:
He
felt that if he had a love he would have hung her picture just facing
the tub so that, lost in the soothing steamings of the hot water, he
might lie and look up at her and muse warmly and sensuously on
her beauty.
Label: f

Text:
NOR DOES HE SPIN

The apartment was kept clean by an English servant with the singularly,
almost theatrically, appropriate name of Bounds, whose technic was
marred only by the fact that he wore a soft collar.
Label: f

Text:
Had he been entirely
Anthony's Bounds this defect would have been summarily remedied, but he
was also the Bounds of two other gentlemen in the neighborhood.
Label: f

Text:
From
eight until eleven in the morning he was entirely Anthony's.
Label: f

Text:
He arrived
with the mail and cooked breakfast.
Label: f

Text:
At nine-thirty he pulled the edge of
Anthony's blanket and spoke a few terse words--Anthony never remembered
clearly what they were and rather suspected they were deprecative; then
he served breakfast on a card-table in the front room, made the bed and,
after asking with some hostility if there was anything else, withdrew.
Label: f

Text: In the mornings, at least once a week, Anthony went to see his broker.
Label: f

Text:
His income was slightly under seven thousand a year, the interest on
money inherited from his mother.
Label: f

Text:
His grandfather, who had never allowed
his own son to graduate from a very liberal allowance, judged that this
sum was sufficient for young Anthony's needs.
Label: f

Text:
Every Christmas he sent
him a five-hundred-dollar bond, which Anthony usually sold, if possible,
as he was always a little, not very, hard up.
Label: f

Text:
The visits to his broker varied from semi-social chats to discussions of
the safety of eight per cent investments, and Anthony always enjoyed
them.
Label: f

Text:
The big trust company building seemed to link him definitely to
the great fortunes whose solidarity he respected and to assure him that
he was adequately chaperoned by the hierarchy of finance.
Label: f

Text:
From these
hurried men he derived the same sense of safety that he had in
contemplating his grandfather's money--even more, for the latter
appeared, vaguely, a demand loan made by the world to Adam Patch's own
moral righteousness, while this money down-town seemed rather to have
been grasped and held by sheer indomitable strengths and tremendous
feats of will; in addition, it seemed more definitely and
explicitly--money.
Label: f

Text:
Closely as Anthony trod on the heels of his income, he considered it to
be enough.
Label: f
f

Text:
This flashes back to the
conversation with his grandfather immediately upon his return from Rome.
Label: f

Text:
He had hoped to find his grandfather dead, but had learned by
telephoning from the pier that Adam Patch was comparatively well
again--the next day he had concealed his disappointment and gone out to
Tarrytown.
Label: f

Text:
Five miles from the station his taxicab entered an
elaborately groomed drive that threaded a veritable maze of walls and
wire fences guarding the estate--this, said the public, was because it
was definitely known that if the Socialists had their way, one of the
first men they'd assassinate would be old Cross Patch.
Label: f

Text:
Anthony was late and the venerable philanthropist was awaiting him in a
glass-walled sun parlor, where he was glancing through the morning
papers for the second time.
Label: f

Text:
His secretary, Edward Shuttleworth--who
before his regeneration had been gambler, saloon-keeper, and general
reprobate--ushered Anthony into the room, exhibiting his redeemer and
benefactor as though he were displaying a treasure of immense value.
Label: f

Text: They shook hands gravely.
Label: f

Text:
"I'm awfully glad to hear you're better,"
Anthony said.
Label: f

Text:
The senior Patch, with an air of having seen his grandson only last
week, pulled out his watch.
Label: f

Text: "Train late?"
Label: f

Text: he asked mildly.
Label: f

Text: It had irritated him to wait for Anthony.
Label: f

Text:
He was under the delusion not
only that in his youth he had handled his practical affairs with the
utmost scrupulousness, even to keeping every engagement on the dot, but
also that this was the direct and primary cause of his success.
Label: f

Text:
"It's been late a good deal this month," he remarked with a shade of
meek accusation in his voice--and then after a long sigh, "Sit down."
Label: f

Text:
Anthony surveyed his grandfather with that tacit amazement which always
attended the sight.
Label: f

Text:
That this feeble, unintelligent old man was
possessed of such power that, yellow journals to the contrary, the men
in the republic whose souls he could not have bought directly or
indirectly would scarcely have populated White Plains, seemed as
impossible to believe as that he had once been a pink-and-white baby.
Label: f

Text:
The span of his seventy-five years had acted as a magic bellows--the
first quarter-century had blown him full with life, and the last had
sucked it all back.
Label: f

Text:
It had sucked in the cheeks and the chest and the
girth of arm and leg.
Label: f

Text:
It had tyrannously demanded his teeth, one by one,
suspended his small eyes in dark-bluish sacks, tweeked out his hairs,
changed him from gray to white in some places, from pink to yellow in
others--callously transposing his colors like a child trying over a
paintbox.
Label: f

Text: Then through his body and his soul it had attacked his brain.
Label: f

Text: It had sent him night-sweats and tears and unfounded dreads.
Label: f

Text:
It had
split his intense normality into credulity and suspicion.
Label: f

Text:
Out of the
coarse material of his enthusiasm it had cut dozens of meek but petulant
obsessions; his energy was shrunk to the bad temper of a spoiled child,
and for his will to power was substituted a fatuous puerile desire for a
land of harps and canticles on earth.
Label: f

Text:
The amenities having been gingerly touched upon, Anthony felt that he
was expected to outline his intentions--and simultaneously a glimmer in
the old man's eye warned him against broaching, for the present, his
desire to live abroad.
Label: f

Text:
He wished that Shuttleworth would have tact
enough to leave the room--he detested Shuttleworth--but the secretary
had settled blandly in a rocker and was dividing between the two Patches
the glances of his faded eyes.
Label: f

Text:
"Now that you're here you ought to _do_ something," said his grandfather
softly, "accomplish something."
Label: f

Text:
Anthony waited for him to speak of "leaving something done when you pass
on."
Label: f

Text:
Then he made a suggestion:

"I thought--it seemed to me that perhaps I'm best qualified to write--"

Adam Patch winced, visualizing a family poet with a long hair and three
mistresses.

"
Label: f

Text: --history," finished Anthony.
Label: f

Text: "History?
Label: f

Text: History of what?
Label: f

Text: The Civil War?
Label: f

Text: The Revolution?"
Label: f

Text: "Why--no, sir.
Label: f

Text: A history of the Middle Ages."
Label: f

Text:
Simultaneously an idea was
born for a history of the Renaissance popes, written from some novel
angle.
Label: f

Text: Still, he was glad he had said "Middle Ages."
Label: f

Text: "Middle Ages?
Label: f

Text: Why not your own country?
Label: f

Text: Something you know about?"
Label: f

Text:
"Well, you see I've lived so much abroad--"

"Why you should write about the Middle Ages, I don't know.
Label: f

Text:
Dark Ages, we
used to call 'em.
Label: f

Text:
Nobody knows what happened, and nobody cares, except
that they're over now."
Label: f

Text:
He continued for some minutes on the uselessness
of such information, touching, naturally, on the Spanish Inquisition and
the "corruption of the monasteries."
Label: f

Text:
Then:

"Do you think you'll be able to do any work in New York--or do you
really intend to work at all?"
Label: f

Text:
This last with soft, almost
imperceptible, cynicism.
Label: f

Text: "Why, yes, I do, sir."
Label: f

Text: "When'll you be done?"
Label: f

Text:
"Well, there'll be an outline, you see--and a lot of preliminary
reading."
Label: f

Text: "I should think you'd have done enough of that already."
Label: f

Text:
The conversation worked itself jerkily toward a rather abrupt
conclusion, when Anthony rose, looked at his watch, and remarked that he
had an engagement with his broker that afternoon.
Label: f

Text:
He had intended to
stay a few days with his grandfather, but he was tired and irritated
from a rough crossing, and quite unwilling to stand a subtle and
sanctimonious browbeating.
Label: f

Text:
He would come out again in a few days,
he said.
Label: f

Text:
Nevertheless, it was due to this encounter that work had come into his
life as a permanent idea.
Label: f

Text:
During the year that had passed since then, he
had made several lists of authorities, he had even experimented with
chapter titles and the division of his work into periods, but not one
line of actual writing existed at present, or seemed likely ever to
exist.
Label: f

Text:
He did nothing--and contrary to the most accredited copy-book
logic, he managed to divert himself with more than average content.
Label: f

Text:
AFTERNOON

It was October in 1913, midway in a week of pleasant days, with the
sunshine loitering in the cross-streets and the atmosphere so languid as
to seem weighted with ghostly falling leaves.
Label: f

Text:
It was pleasant to sit
lazily by the open window finishing a chapter of "Erewhon."
Label: f

Text:
It was
pleasant to yawn about five, toss the book on a table, and saunter
humming along the hall to his bath.
Label: f

Text:
"To ... you ... beaut-if-ul lady,"

he was singing as he turned on the tap.
Label: f

Text:
"I raise ... my ... eyes;
To ... you ... beaut-if-ul la-a-dy
My ... heart ... cries--"

He raised his voice to compete with the flood of water pouring into the
tub, and as he looked at the picture of Hazel Dawn upon the wall he put
an imaginary violin to his shoulder and softly caressed it with a
phantom bow.
Label: f

Text:
Through his closed lips he made a humming noise, which he
vaguely imagined resembled the sound of a violin.
Label: f

Text:
After a moment his
hands ceased their gyrations and wandered to his shirt, which he began
to unfasten.
Label: f

Text:
Stripped, and adopting an athletic posture like the
tiger-skin man in the advertisement, he regarded himself with some
satisfaction in the mirror, breaking off to dabble a tentative foot in
the tub.
Label: f

Text:
Readjusting a faucet and indulging in a few preliminary grunts,
he slid in.
Label: f

Text:
Once accustomed to the temperature of the water he relaxed into a state
of drowsy content.
Label: f

Text:
When he finished his bath he would dress leisurely
and walk down Fifth Avenue to the Ritz, where he had an appointment for
dinner with his two most frequent companions, Dick Caramel and Maury
Noble.
Label: f

Text:
Afterward he and Maury were going to the theatre--Caramel would
probably trot home and work on his book, which ought to be finished
pretty soon.
Label: f

Text: Anthony was glad _he_ wasn't going to work on _his_ book.
Label: f

Text:
The notion of
sitting down and conjuring up, not only words in which to clothe
thoughts but thoughts worthy of being clothed--the whole thing was
absurdly beyond his desires.
Label: f

Text:
Emerging from his bath he polished himself with the meticulous attention
of a bootblack.
Label: f
f

Text:
He lit a cigarette, tossed the match out the open top of the window,
then paused in his tracks with the cigarette two inches from his
mouth--which fell faintly ajar.
Label: f

Text:
His eyes were focussed upon a spot of
brilliant color on the roof of a house farther down the alley.
Label: f

Text:
It was a girl in a red negligé, silk surely, drying her hair by the
still hot sun of late afternoon.
Label: f

Text:
His whistle died upon the stiff air of
the room; he walked cautiously another step nearer the window with a
sudden impression that she was beautiful.
Label: f

Text:
Sitting on the stone parapet
beside her was a cushion the same color as her garment and she was
leaning both arms upon it as she looked down into the sunny areaway,
where Anthony could hear children playing.
Label: f

Text: He watched her for several minutes.
Label: f

Text:
Something was stirred in him,
something not accounted for by the warm smell of the afternoon or the
triumphant vividness of red.
Label: f

Text:
He felt persistently that the girl was
beautiful--then of a sudden he understood: it was her distance, not a
rare and precious distance of soul but still distance, if only in
terrestrial yards.
Label: f

Text:
The autumn air was between them, and the roofs and
the blurred voices.
Label: f

Text:
Yet for a not altogether explained second, posing
perversely in time, his emotion had been nearer to adoration than in the
deepest kiss he had ever known.
Label: f

Text:
He finished his dressing, found a black bow tie and adjusted it
carefully by the three-sided mirror in the bathroom.
Label: f

Text:
Then yielding to an
impulse he walked quickly into the bedroom and again looked out the
window.
Label: f

Text:
The woman was standing up now; she had tossed her hair back and
he had a full view of her.
Label: f

Text:
She was fat, full thirty-five, utterly
undistinguished.
Label: f

Text:
Making a clicking noise with his mouth he returned to
the bathroom and reparted his hair.
Label: f

Text:
"To ... you ... beaut-if-ul lady,"

he sang lightly,

"I raise ... my ... eyes--"

Then with a last soothing brush that left an iridescent surface of sheer
gloss he left his bathroom and his apartment and walked down Fifth
Avenue to the Ritz-Carlton.
Label: f

Text:
THREE MEN

At seven Anthony and his friend Maury Noble are sitting at a corner
table on the cool roof.
Label: f

Text:
Maury Noble is like nothing so much as a large
slender and imposing cat.
Label: f

Text:
His eyes are narrow and full of incessant,
protracted blinks.
Label: f

Text:
His hair is smooth and flat, as though it has been
licked by a possible--and, if so, Herculean--mother-cat.
Label: f

Text:
﻿                                I

In my younger and more vulnerable years my father gave me some advice
that I’ve been turning over in my mind ever since.
Label: f

Text:
“Whenever you feel like criticizing anyone,” he told me, “just
remember that all the people in this world haven’t had the advantages
that you’ve had.”

He didn’t say any more, but we’ve always been unusually communicative
in a reserved way, and I understood that he meant a great deal more
than that.
Label: f

Text:
In consequence, I’m inclined to reserve all judgements, a
habit that has opened up many curious natures to me and also made me
the victim of not a few veteran bores.
Label: f

Text:
The abnormal mind is quick to
detect and attach itself to this quality when it appears in a normal
person, and so it came about that in college I was unjustly accused of
being a politician, because I was privy to the secret griefs of wild,
unknown men.
Label: f

Text:
Most of the confidences were unsought—frequently I have
feigned sleep, preoccupation, or a hostile levity when I realized by
some unmistakable sign that an intimate revelation was quivering on
the horizon; for the intimate revelations of young men, or at least
the terms in which they express them, are usually plagiaristic and
marred by obvious suppressions.
Label: f

Text:
Reserving judgements is a matter of
infinite hope.
Label: f

Text:
I am still a little afraid of missing something if I
forget that, as my father snobbishly suggested, and I snobbishly
repeat, a sense of the fundamental decencies is parcelled out
unequally at birth.
Label: f

Text:
And, after boasting this way of my tolerance, I come to the admission
that it has a limit.
Label: f

Text:
Conduct may be founded on the hard rock or the
wet marshes, but after a certain point I don’t care what it’s founded
on.
Label: f

Text:
When I came back from the East last autumn I felt that I wanted
the world to be in uniform and at a sort of moral attention forever; I
wanted no more riotous excursions with privileged glimpses into the
human heart.
Label: f

Text:
Only Gatsby, the man who gives his name to this book, was
exempt from my reaction—Gatsby, who represented everything for which I
have an unaffected scorn.
Label: f

Text:
If personality is an unbroken series of
successful gestures, then there was something gorgeous about him, some
heightened sensitivity to the promises of life, as if he were related
to one of those intricate machines that register earthquakes ten
thousand miles away.
Label: f

Text:
This responsiveness had nothing to do with that
flabby impressionability which is dignified under the name of the
“creative temperament”—it was an extraordinary gift for hope, a
romantic readiness such as I have never found in any other person and
which it is not likely I shall ever find again.
Label: f

Text:
No—Gatsby turned out
all right at the end; it is what preyed on Gatsby, what foul dust
floated in the wake of his dreams that temporarily closed out my
interest in the abortive sorrows and short-winded elations of men.
Label: f

Text:
------------------------------------------------------------------------

My family have been prominent, well-to-do people in this Middle
Western city for three generations.
Label: f

Text:
The Carraways are something of a
clan, and we have a tradition that we’re descended from the Dukes of
Buccleuch, but the actual founder of my line was my grandfather’s
brother, who came here in fifty-one, sent a substitute to the Civil
War, and started the wholesale hardware business that my father
carries on today.
Label: f

Text:
I never saw this great-uncle, but I’m supposed to look like him—with
special reference to the rather hard-boiled painting that hangs in
father’s office.
Label: f

Text:
I graduated from New Haven in 1915, just a quarter of
a century after my father, and a little later I participated in that
delayed Teutonic migration known as the Great War.
Label: f

Text:
I enjoyed the
counter-raid so thoroughly that I came back restless.
Label: f

Text:
Instead of being
the warm centre of the world, the Middle West now seemed like the
ragged edge of the universe—so I decided to go East and learn the bond
business.
Label: f

Text:
Everybody I knew was in the bond business, so I supposed it
could support one more single man.
Label: f

Text:
All my aunts and uncles talked it
over as if they were choosing a prep school for me, and finally said,
“Why—ye-es,” with very grave, hesitant faces.
Label: f

Text:
Father agreed to finance
me for a year, and after various delays I came East, permanently, I
thought, in the spring of twenty-two.
Label: f

Text:
The practical thing was to find rooms in the city, but it was a warm
season, and I had just left a country of wide lawns and friendly
trees, so when a young man at the office suggested that we take a
house together in a commuting town, it sounded like a great idea.
Label: f

Text:
He
found the house, a weather-beaten cardboard bungalow at eighty a
month, but at the last minute the firm ordered him to Washington, and
I went out to the country alone.
Label: f

Text:
I had a dog—at least I had him for a
few days until he ran away—and an old Dodge and a Finnish woman, who
made my bed and cooked breakfast and muttered Finnish wisdom to
herself over the electric stove.
Label: f

Text:
It was lonely for a day or so until one morning some man, more
recently arrived than I, stopped me on the road.
Label: f

Text: “How do you get to West Egg village?” he asked helplessly.
Label: f

Text: I told him.
Label: f

Text: And as I walked on I was lonely no longer.
Label: f

Text:
I was a guide,
a pathfinder, an original settler.
Label: f

Text:
He had casually conferred on me the
freedom of the neighbourhood.
Label: f

Text:
And so with the sunshine and the great bursts of leaves growing on the
trees, just as things grow in fast movies, I had that familiar
conviction that life was beginning over again with the summer.
Label: f

Text:
There was so much to read, for one thing, and so much fine health to
be pulled down out of the young breath-giving air.
Label: f

Text:
I bought a dozen
volumes on banking and credit and investment securities, and they
stood on my shelf in red and gold like new money from the mint,
promising to unfold the shining secrets that only Midas and Morgan and
Maecenas knew.
Label: f

Text:
And I had the high intention of reading many other
books besides.
Label: f

Text:
I was rather literary in college—one year I wrote a
series of very solemn and obvious editorials for the Yale News—and now
I was going to bring back all such things into my life and become
again that most limited of all specialists, the “well-rounded man.”
This isn’t just an epigram—life is much more successfully looked at
from a single window, after all.
Label: f

Text:
It was a matter of chance that I should have rented a house in one of
the strangest communities in North America.
Label: f

Text:
It was on that slender
riotous island which extends itself due east of New York—and where
there are, among other natural curiosities, two unusual formations of
land.
Label: f

Text:
Twenty miles from the city a pair of enormous eggs, identical in
contour and separated only by a courtesy bay, jut out into the most
domesticated body of salt water in the Western hemisphere, the great
wet barnyard of Long Island Sound.
Label: f

Text:
They are not perfect ovals—like the
egg in the Columbus story, they are both crushed flat at the contact
end—but their physical resemblance must be a source of perpetual
wonder to the gulls that fly overhead.
Label: f

Text:
To the wingless a more
interesting phenomenon is their dissimilarity in every particular
except shape and size.
Label: f

Text:
I lived at West Egg, the—well, the less fashionable of the two, though
this is a most superficial tag to express the bizarre and not a little
sinister contrast between them.
Label: f

Text:
My house was at the very tip of the
egg, only fifty yards from the Sound, and squeezed between two huge
places that rented for twelve or fifteen thousand a season.
Label: f

Text:
The one on
my right was a colossal affair by any standard—it was a factual
imitation of some Hôtel de Ville in Normandy, with a tower on one
side, spanking new under a thin beard of raw ivy, and a marble
swimming pool, and more than forty acres of lawn and garden.
Label: f

Text:
It was
Gatsby’s mansion.
