think it would be a very good thing for Miss Taylor if Mr. Weston were
to marry her,’ and saying it again to yourself every now and then
afterwards, why do you talk of success?
Label: jane

Text: Where is your merit?
Label: jane

Text:
What are
you proud of?
Label: jane

Text:
You made a lucky guess; and _that_ is all that can be
said.”

“And have you never known the pleasure and triumph of a lucky guess?—I
pity you.—I thought you cleverer—for, depend upon it a lucky guess is
never merely luck.
Label: jane

Text: There is always some talent in it.
Label: jane

Text:
And as to my poor
word ‘success,’ which you quarrel with, I do not know that I am so
entirely without any claim to it.
Label: jane
jane

Text:
If I had not promoted Mr. Weston’s visits here, and given
many little encouragements, and smoothed many little matters, it might
not have come to any thing after all.
Label: jane

Text:
I think you must know Hartfield
enough to comprehend that.”

“A straightforward, open-hearted man like Weston, and a rational,
unaffected woman like Miss Taylor, may be safely left to manage their
own concerns.
Label: jane

Text:
You are more likely to have done harm to yourself, than
good to them, by interference.”

“Emma never thinks of herself, if she can do good to others,” rejoined
Mr. Woodhouse, understanding but in part.
Label: jane

Text:
“But, my dear, pray do not
make any more matches; they are silly things, and break up one’s family
circle grievously.”

“Only one more, papa; only for Mr. Elton.
Label: jane

Text: Poor Mr. Elton!
Label: jane

Text:
You like Mr.
Elton, papa,—I must look about for a wife for him.
Label: jane

Text:
There is nobody in
Highbury who deserves him—and he has been here a whole year, and has
fitted up his house so comfortably, that it would be a shame to have
him single any longer—and I thought when he was joining their hands
to-day, he looked so very much as if he would like to have the same
kind office done for him!
Label: jane

Text:
I think very well of Mr. Elton, and this is
the only way I have of doing him a service.”

“Mr.
Label: jane

Text:
Elton is a very pretty young man, to be sure, and a very good
young man, and I have a great regard for him.
Label: jane

Text:
But if you want to shew
him any attention, my dear, ask him to come and dine with us some day.
Label: jane

Text: That will be a much better thing.
Label: jane

Text:
I dare say Mr. Knightley will be so
kind as to meet him.”

“With a great deal of pleasure, sir, at any time,” said Mr. Knightley,
laughing, “and I agree with you entirely, that it will be a much better
thing.
Label: jane

Text:
Invite him to dinner, Emma, and help him to the best of the fish
and the chicken, but leave him to chuse his own wife.
Label: jane

Text:
Depend upon it, a
man of six or seven-and-twenty can take care of himself.”




CHAPTER II


Mr. Weston was a native of Highbury, and born of a respectable family,
which for the last two or three generations had been rising into
gentility and property.
Label: jane

Text:
He had received a good education, but, on
succeeding early in life to a small independence, had become indisposed
for any of the more homely pursuits in which his brothers were engaged,
and had satisfied an active, cheerful mind and social temper by
entering into the militia of his county, then embodied.
Label: jane

Text:
Captain Weston was a general favourite; and when the chances of his
military life had introduced him to Miss Churchill, of a great
Yorkshire family, and Miss Churchill fell in love with him, nobody was
surprized, except her brother and his wife, who had never seen him, and
who were full of pride and importance, which the connexion would
offend.
Label: jane

Text:
Miss Churchill, however, being of age, and with the full command of her
fortune—though her fortune bore no proportion to the family-estate—was
not to be dissuaded from the marriage, and it took place, to the
infinite mortification of Mr. and Mrs. Churchill, who threw her off
with due decorum.
Label: jane

Text:
It was an unsuitable connexion, and did not produce
much happiness.
Label: jane

Text:
Mrs. Weston ought to have found more in it, for she had
a husband whose warm heart and sweet temper made him think every thing
due to her in return for the great goodness of being in love with him;
but though she had one sort of spirit, she had not the best.
Label: jane

Text:
She had
resolution enough to pursue her own will in spite of her brother, but
not enough to refrain from unreasonable regrets at that brother’s
unreasonable anger, nor from missing the luxuries of her former home.
Label: jane

Text:
They lived beyond their income, but still it was nothing in comparison
of Enscombe: she did not cease to love her husband, but she wanted at
once to be the wife of Captain Weston, and Miss Churchill of Enscombe.
Label: jane

Text:
Captain Weston, who had been considered, especially by the Churchills,
as making such an amazing match, was proved to have much the worst of
the bargain; for when his wife died, after a three years’ marriage, he
was rather a poorer man than at first, and with a child to maintain.
Label: jane

Text: From the expense of the child, however, he was soon relieved.
Label: jane

Text:
The boy
had, with the additional softening claim of a lingering illness of his
mother’s, been the means of a sort of reconciliation; and Mr. and Mrs.
Churchill, having no children of their own, nor any other young
creature of equal kindred to care for, offered to take the whole charge
of the little Frank soon after her decease.
Label: jane

Text:
Some scruples and some
reluctance the widower-father may be supposed to have felt; but as they
were overcome by other considerations, the child was given up to the
care and the wealth of the Churchills, and he had only his own comfort
to seek, and his own situation to improve as he could.
Label: jane

Text: A complete change of life became desirable.
Label: jane

Text:
He quitted the militia and
engaged in trade, having brothers already established in a good way in
London, which afforded him a favourable opening.
Label: jane

Text:
It was a concern which
brought just employment enough.
Label: jane

Text:
He had still a small house in Highbury,
where most of his leisure days were spent; and between useful
occupation and the pleasures of society, the next eighteen or twenty
years of his life passed cheerfully away.
Label: jane

Text:
He had, by that time,
realised an easy competence—enough to secure the purchase of a little
estate adjoining Highbury, which he had always longed for—enough to
marry a woman as portionless even as Miss Taylor, and to live according
to the wishes of his own friendly and social disposition.
Label: jane

Text:
It was now some time since Miss Taylor had begun to influence his
schemes; but as it was not the tyrannic influence of youth on youth, it
had not shaken his determination of never settling till he could
purchase Randalls, and the sale of Randalls was long looked forward to;
but he had gone steadily on, with these objects in view, till they were
accomplished.
Label: jane

Text:
He had made his fortune, bought his house, and obtained
his wife; and was beginning a new period of existence, with every
probability of greater happiness than in any yet passed through.
Label: jane

Text:
He had
never been an unhappy man; his own temper had secured him from that,
even in his first marriage; but his second must shew him how delightful
a well-judging and truly amiable woman could be, and must give him the
pleasantest proof of its being a great deal better to choose than to be
chosen, to excite gratitude than to feel it.
Label: jane

Text:
He had only himself to please in his choice: his fortune was his own;
for as to Frank, it was more than being tacitly brought up as his
uncle’s heir, it had become so avowed an adoption as to have him assume
the name of Churchill on coming of age.
Label: jane

Text:
It was most unlikely,
therefore, that he should ever want his father’s assistance.
Label: jane

Text:
His father
had no apprehension of it.
Label: jane

Text:
The aunt was a capricious woman, and
governed her husband entirely; but it was not in Mr. Weston’s nature to
imagine that any caprice could be strong enough to affect one so dear,
and, as he believed, so deservedly dear.
Label: jane

Text:
He saw his son every year in
London, and was proud of him; and his fond report of him as a very fine
young man had made Highbury feel a sort of pride in him too.
Label: jane

Text:
He was
looked on as sufficiently belonging to the place to make his merits and
prospects a kind of common concern.
Label: jane

Text:
Mr. Frank Churchill was one of the boasts of Highbury, and a lively
curiosity to see him prevailed, though the compliment was so little
returned that he had never been there in his life.
Label: jane

Text:
His coming to visit
his father had been often talked of but never achieved.
Label: jane

Text:
Now, upon his father’s marriage, it was very generally proposed, as a
most proper attention, that the visit should take place.
Label: jane

Text:
There was not
a dissentient voice on the subject, either when Mrs. Perry drank tea
with Mrs. and Miss Bates, or when Mrs. and Miss Bates returned the
visit.
Label: jane

Text:
Now was the time for Mr. Frank Churchill to come among them; and
the hope strengthened when it was understood that he had written to his
new mother on the occasion.
Label: jane

Text:
For a few days, every morning visit in
Highbury included some mention of the handsome letter Mrs. Weston had
received.
Label: jane

Text:
“I suppose you have heard of the handsome letter Mr. Frank
Churchill has written to Mrs. Weston?
Label: jane

Text:
I understand it was a very
handsome letter, indeed.
Label: jane

Text: Mr. Woodhouse told me of it.
Label: jane

Text:
Mr. Woodhouse saw
the letter, and he says he never saw such a handsome letter in his
life.”

It was, indeed, a highly prized letter.
Label: jane

Text:
Mrs. Weston had, of course,
formed a very favourable idea of the young man; and such a pleasing
attention was an irresistible proof of his great good sense, and a most
welcome addition to every source and every expression of congratulation
which her marriage had already secured.
Label: jane

Text:
She felt herself a most
fortunate woman; and she had lived long enough to know how fortunate
she might well be thought, where the only regret was for a partial
separation from friends whose friendship for her had never cooled, and
who could ill bear to part with her.
Label: jane

Text:
She knew that at times she must be missed; and could not think, without
pain, of Emma’s losing a single pleasure, or suffering an hour’s ennui,
from the want of her companionableness: but dear Emma was of no feeble
character; she was more equal to her situation than most girls would
have been, and had sense, and energy, and spirits that might be hoped
would bear her well and happily through its little difficulties and
privations.
Label: jane

Text:
And then there was such comfort in the very easy distance
of Randalls from Hartfield, so convenient for even solitary female
walking, and in Mr. Weston’s disposition and circumstances, which would
make the approaching season no hindrance to their spending half the
evenings in the week together.
Label: jane

Text:
Her situation was altogether the subject of hours of gratitude to Mrs.
Weston, and of moments only of regret; and her satisfaction—her more
than satisfaction—her cheerful enjoyment, was so just and so apparent,
that Emma, well as she knew her father, was sometimes taken by surprize
at his being still able to pity ‘poor Miss Taylor,’ when they left her
at Randalls in the centre of every domestic comfort, or saw her go away
in the evening attended by her pleasant husband to a carriage of her
own.
Label: jane

Text:
But never did she go without Mr. Woodhouse’s giving a gentle sigh,
and saying, “Ah, poor Miss Taylor!
Label: jane

Text:
She would be very glad to stay.”

There was no recovering Miss Taylor—nor much likelihood of ceasing to
pity her; but a few weeks brought some alleviation to Mr. Woodhouse.
Label: jane

Text:
The compliments of his neighbours were over; he was no longer teased by
being wished joy of so sorrowful an event; and the wedding-cake, which
had been a great distress to him, was all eat up.
Label: jane

Text:
His own stomach could
bear nothing rich, and he could never believe other people to be
different from himself.
Label: jane

Text:
What was unwholesome to him he regarded as
unfit for any body; and he had, therefore, earnestly tried to dissuade
them from having any wedding-cake at all, and when that proved vain, as
earnestly tried to prevent any body’s eating it.
Label: jane

Text:
He had been at the
pains of consulting Mr. Perry, the apothecary, on the subject.
Label: jane

Text:
Mr.
Perry was an intelligent, gentlemanlike man, whose frequent visits were
one of the comforts of Mr. Woodhouse’s life; and upon being applied to,
he could not but acknowledge (though it seemed rather against the bias
of inclination) that wedding-cake might certainly disagree with
many—perhaps with most people, unless taken moderately.
Label: jane

Text:
With such an
opinion, in confirmation of his own, Mr. Woodhouse hoped to influence
every visitor of the newly married pair; but still the cake was eaten;
and there was no rest for his benevolent nerves till it was all gone.
Label: jane

Text:
There was a strange rumour in Highbury of all the little Perrys being
seen with a slice of Mrs. Weston’s wedding-cake in their hands: but Mr.
Woodhouse would never believe it.
Label: jane

Text:
CHAPTER III


Mr. Woodhouse was fond of society in his own way.
Label: jane

Text:
He liked very much to
have his friends come and see him; and from various united causes, from
his long residence at Hartfield, and his good nature, from his fortune,
his house, and his daughter, he could command the visits of his own
little circle, in a great measure, as he liked.
Label: jane

Text:
He had not much
intercourse with any families beyond that circle; his horror of late
hours, and large dinner-parties, made him unfit for any acquaintance
but such as would visit him on his own terms.
Label: jane

Text:
Fortunately for him,
Highbury, including Randalls in the same parish, and Donwell Abbey in
the parish adjoining, the seat of Mr. Knightley, comprehended many
such.
Label: jane

Text:
Not unfrequently, through Emma’s persuasion, he had some of the
chosen and the best to dine with him: but evening parties were what he
preferred; and, unless he fancied himself at any time unequal to
company, there was scarcely an evening in the week in which Emma could
not make up a card-table for him.
Label: jane

Text:
Real, long-standing regard brought the Westons and Mr. Knightley; and
by Mr. Elton, a young man living alone without liking it, the privilege
of exchanging any vacant evening of his own blank solitude for the
elegancies and society of Mr. Woodhouse’s drawing-room, and the smiles
of his lovely daughter, was in no danger of being thrown away.
Label: jane

Text:
After these came a second set; among the most come-at-able of whom were
Mrs. and Miss Bates, and Mrs. Goddard, three ladies almost always at
the service of an invitation from Hartfield, and who were fetched and
carried home so often, that Mr. Woodhouse thought it no hardship for
either James or the horses.
Label: jane

Text:
Had it taken place only once a year, it
would have been a grievance.
Label: jane

Text:
Mrs. Bates, the widow of a former vicar of Highbury, was a very old
lady, almost past every thing but tea and quadrille.
Label: jane

Text:
She lived with her
single daughter in a very small way, and was considered with all the
regard and respect which a harmless old lady, under such untoward
circumstances, can excite.
Label: jane

Text:
Her daughter enjoyed a most uncommon degree
of popularity for a woman neither young, handsome, rich, nor married.
Label: jane

Text:
Miss Bates stood in the very worst predicament in the world for having
much of the public favour; and she had no intellectual superiority to
make atonement to herself, or frighten those who might hate her into
outward respect.
Label: jane

Text: She had never boasted either beauty or cleverness.
Label: jane

Text:
Her
youth had passed without distinction, and her middle of life was
devoted to the care of a failing mother, and the endeavour to make a
small income go as far as possible.
Label: jane

Text:
And yet she was a happy woman, and
a woman whom no one named without good-will.
Label: jane

Text:
It was her own universal
good-will and contented temper which worked such wonders.
Label: jane

Text:
She loved
every body, was interested in every body’s happiness, quicksighted to
every body’s merits; thought herself a most fortunate creature, and
surrounded with blessings in such an excellent mother, and so many good
neighbours and friends, and a home that wanted for nothing.
Label: jane

Text:
The
simplicity and cheerfulness of her nature, her contented and grateful
spirit, were a recommendation to every body, and a mine of felicity to
herself.
Label: jane

Text:
She was a great talker upon little matters, which exactly
suited Mr. Woodhouse, full of trivial communications and harmless
gossip.
Label: jane

Text:
Mrs. Goddard was the mistress of a School—not of a seminary, or an
establishment, or any thing which professed, in long sentences of
refined nonsense, to combine liberal acquirements with elegant
morality, upon new principles and new systems—and where young ladies
for enormous pay might be screwed out of health and into vanity—but a
real, honest, old-fashioned Boarding-school, where a reasonable
quantity of accomplishments were sold at a reasonable price, and where
girls might be sent to be out of the way, and scramble themselves into
a little education, without any danger of coming back prodigies.
Label: jane

Text:
Mrs.
Goddard’s school was in high repute—and very deservedly; for Highbury
was reckoned a particularly healthy spot: she had an ample house and
garden, gave the children plenty of wholesome food, let them run about
a great deal in the summer, and in winter dressed their chilblains with
her own hands.
Label: jane

Text:
It was no wonder that a train of twenty young couple now
walked after her to church.
Label: jane

Text: ﻿Chapter I.]
Label: jane

Text:
It is a truth universally acknowledged, that a single man in possession
of a good fortune must be in want of a wife.
Label: jane

Text:
However little known the feelings or views of such a man may be on his
first entering a neighbourhood, this truth is so well fixed in the minds
of the surrounding families, that he is considered as the rightful
property of some one or other of their daughters.
Label: jane

Text:
“My dear Mr. Bennet,” said his lady to him one day, “have you heard that
Netherfield Park is let at last?”

Mr. Bennet replied that he had not.
Label: jane

Text:
“But it is,” returned she; “for Mrs. Long has just been here, and she
told me all about it.”

Mr. Bennet made no answer.
Label: jane

Text: “Do not you want to know who has taken it?” cried his wife, impatiently.
Label: jane

Text:
“_You_ want to tell me, and I have no objection to hearing it.”

[Illustration:

“He came down to see the place”

[_Copyright 1894 by George Allen._]]

This was invitation enough.
Label: jane

Text:
“Why, my dear, you must know, Mrs. Long says that Netherfield is taken
by a young man of large fortune from the north of England; that he came
down on Monday in a chaise and four to see the place, and was so much
delighted with it that he agreed with Mr. Morris immediately; that he is
to take possession before Michaelmas, and some of his servants are to be
in the house by the end of next week.”

“What is his name?”

“Bingley.”

“Is he married or single?”

“Oh, single, my dear, to be sure!
Label: jane

Text:
A single man of large fortune; four or
five thousand a year.
Label: jane

Text:
What a fine thing for our girls!”

“How so?
Label: jane

Text:
how can it affect them?”

“My dear Mr. Bennet,” replied his wife, “how can you be so tiresome?
Label: jane

Text:
You
must know that I am thinking of his marrying one of them.”

“Is that his design in settling here?”

“Design?
Label: jane

Text: Nonsense, how can you talk so!
Label: jane

Text:
But it is very likely that he
_may_ fall in love with one of them, and therefore you must visit him as
soon as he comes.”

“I see no occasion for that.
Label: jane

Text:
You and the girls may go--or you may send
them by themselves, which perhaps will be still better; for as you are
as handsome as any of them, Mr. Bingley might like you the best of the
party.”

“My dear, you flatter me.
Label: jane

Text:
I certainly _have_ had my share of beauty, but
I do not pretend to be anything extraordinary now.
Label: jane

Text:
When a woman has five
grown-up daughters, she ought to give over thinking of her own beauty.”

“In such cases, a woman has not often much beauty to think of.”

“But, my dear, you must indeed go and see Mr. Bingley when he comes into
the neighbourhood.”

“It is more than I engage for, I assure you.”

“But consider your daughters.
Label: jane

Text:
Only think what an establishment it would
be for one of them.
Label: jane

Text:
Sir William and Lady Lucas are determined to go,
merely on that account; for in general, you know, they visit no new
comers.
Label: jane

Text:
Indeed you must go, for it will be impossible for _us_ to visit
him, if you do not.”

“You are over scrupulous, surely.
Label: jane

Text:
I dare say Mr. Bingley will be very
glad to see you; and I will send a few lines by you to assure him of my
hearty consent to his marrying whichever he chooses of the girls--though
I must throw in a good word for my little Lizzy.”

“I desire you will do no such thing.
Label: jane

Text:
Lizzy is not a bit better than the
others: and I am sure she is not half so handsome as Jane, nor half so
good-humoured as Lydia.
Label: jane

Text:
But you are always giving _her_ the preference.”

“They have none of them much to recommend them,” replied he: “they are
all silly and ignorant like other girls; but Lizzy has something more of
quickness than her sisters.”

“Mr.
Label: jane

Text: Bennet, how can you abuse your own children in such a way?
Label: jane

Text:
You take
delight in vexing me.
Label: jane

Text:
You have no compassion on my poor nerves.”

“You mistake me, my dear.
Label: jane

Text: I have a high respect for your nerves.
Label: jane

Text:
They
are my old friends.
Label: jane

Text:
I have heard you mention them with consideration
these twenty years at least.”

“Ah, you do not know what I suffer.”

“But I hope you will get over it, and live to see many young men of four
thousand a year come into the neighbourhood.”

“It will be no use to us, if twenty such should come, since you will not
visit them.”

“Depend upon it, my dear, that when there are twenty, I will visit them
all.”

Mr. Bennet was so odd a mixture of quick parts, sarcastic humour,
reserve, and caprice, that the experience of three-and-twenty years had
been insufficient to make his wife understand his character.
Label: jane

Text:
_Her_ mind
was less difficult to develope.
Label: jane

Text:
She was a woman of mean understanding,
little information, and uncertain temper.
Label: jane

Text:
When she was discontented, she
fancied herself nervous.
Label: jane

Text:
The business of her life was to get her
daughters married: its solace was visiting and news.
Label: jane

Text: [Illustration: M^{r.} & M^{rs.}
Label: jane

Text:
Bennet

[_Copyright 1894 by George Allen._]]




[Illustration:

“I hope Mr. Bingley will like it”

[_Copyright 1894 by George Allen._]]




CHAPTER II.
Label: jane

Text:
[Illustration]

Mr. Bennet was among the earliest of those who waited on Mr. Bingley.
Label: jane

Text:
He
had always intended to visit him, though to the last always assuring his
wife that he should not go; and till the evening after the visit was
paid she had no knowledge of it.
Label: jane

Text:
It was then disclosed in the following
manner.
Label: jane

Text:
Observing his second daughter employed in trimming a hat, he
suddenly addressed her with,--

“I hope Mr. Bingley will like it, Lizzy.”

“We are not in a way to know _what_ Mr. Bingley likes,” said her mother,
resentfully, “since we are not to visit.”

“But you forget, mamma,” said Elizabeth, “that we shall meet him at the
assemblies, and that Mrs. Long has promised to introduce him.”

“I do not believe Mrs. Long will do any such thing.
Label: jane

Text:
She has two nieces
of her own.
Label: jane

Text:
She is a selfish, hypocritical woman, and I have no opinion
of her.”

“No more have I,” said Mr. Bennet; “and I am glad to find that you do
not depend on her serving you.”

Mrs. Bennet deigned not to make any reply; but, unable to contain
herself, began scolding one of her daughters.
Label: jane

Text: “Don’t keep coughing so, Kitty, for heaven’s sake!
Label: jane

Text:
Have a little
compassion on my nerves.
Label: jane

Text:
You tear them to pieces.”

“Kitty has no discretion in her coughs,” said her father; “she times
them ill.”

“I do not cough for my own amusement,” replied Kitty, fretfully.
Label: jane

Text:
“When
is your next ball to be, Lizzy?”

“To-morrow fortnight.”

“Ay, so it is,” cried her mother, “and Mrs. Long does not come back till
the day before; so, it will be impossible for her to introduce him, for
she will not know him herself.”

“Then, my dear, you may have the advantage of your friend, and introduce
Mr. Bingley to _her_.”

“Impossible, Mr. Bennet, impossible, when I am not acquainted with him
myself; how can you be so teasing?”

“I honour your circumspection.
Label: jane

Text:
A fortnight’s acquaintance is certainly
very little.
Label: jane

Text:
One cannot know what a man really is by the end of a
fortnight.
Label: jane

Text:
But if _we_ do not venture, somebody else will; and after
all, Mrs. Long and her nieces must stand their chance; and, therefore,
as she will think it an act of kindness, if you decline the office, I
will take it on myself.”

The girls stared at their father.
Label: jane

Text:
Mrs. Bennet said only, “Nonsense,
nonsense!”

“What can be the meaning of that emphatic exclamation?” cried he.
Label: jane

Text:
“Do
you consider the forms of introduction, and the stress that is laid on
them, as nonsense?
Label: jane

Text: I cannot quite agree with you _there_.
Label: jane

Text:
What say you,
Mary?
Label: jane

Text:
For you are a young lady of deep reflection, I know, and read
great books, and make extracts.”

Mary wished to say something very sensible, but knew not how.
Label: jane

Text:
“While Mary is adjusting her ideas,” he continued, “let us return to Mr.
Bingley.”

“I am sick of Mr. Bingley,” cried his wife.
Label: jane

Text: “I am sorry to hear _that_; but why did you not tell me so before?
Label: jane

Text:
If I
had known as much this morning, I certainly would not have called on
him.
Label: jane

Text:
It is very unlucky; but as I have actually paid the visit, we
cannot escape the acquaintance now.”

The astonishment of the ladies was just what he wished--that of Mrs.
Bennet perhaps surpassing the rest; though when the first tumult of joy
was over, she began to declare that it was what she had expected all the
while.
Label: jane

Text: “How good it was in you, my dear Mr. Bennet!
Label: jane

Text:
But I knew I should
persuade you at last.
Label: jane

Text:
I was sure you loved your girls too well to
neglect such an acquaintance.
Label: jane

Text: Well, how pleased I am!
Label: jane

Text:
And it is such a
good joke, too, that you should have gone this morning, and never said a
word about it till now.”

“Now, Kitty, you may cough as much as you choose,” said Mr. Bennet; and,
as he spoke, he left the room, fatigued with the raptures of his wife.
Label: jane

Text:
“What an excellent father you have, girls,” said she, when the door was
shut.
Label: jane

Text:
“I do not know how you will ever make him amends for his kindness;
or me either, for that matter.
Label: jane

Text:
At our time of life, it is not so
pleasant, I can tell you, to be making new acquaintances every day; but
for your sakes we would do anything.
Label: jane

Text:
Lydia, my love, though you _are_
the youngest, I dare say Mr. Bingley will dance with you at the next
ball.”

“Oh,” said Lydia, stoutly, “I am not afraid; for though I _am_ the
youngest, I’m the tallest.”

The rest of the evening was spent in conjecturing how soon he would
return Mr. Bennet’s visit, and determining when they should ask him to
dinner.
Label: jane

Text:
[Illustration: “I’m the tallest”]




[Illustration:

     “He rode a black horse”
]




CHAPTER III.
Label: jane

Text:
[Illustration]

Not all that Mrs. Bennet, however, with the assistance of her five
daughters, could ask on the subject, was sufficient to draw from her
husband any satisfactory description of Mr. Bingley.
Label: jane

Text:
They attacked him
in various ways, with barefaced questions, ingenious suppositions, and
distant surmises; but he eluded the skill of them all; and they were at
last obliged to accept the second-hand intelligence of their neighbour,
Lady Lucas.
Label: jane

Text: Her report was highly favourable.
Label: jane

Text:
Sir William had been
delighted with him.
Label: jane

Text:
He was quite young, wonderfully handsome, extremely
agreeable, and, to crown the whole, he meant to be at the next assembly
with a large party.
Label: jane

Text: Nothing could be more delightful!
Label: jane

Text:
To be fond of
dancing was a certain step towards falling in love; and very lively
hopes of Mr. Bingley’s heart were entertained.
Label: jane

Text:
“If I can but see one of my daughters happily settled at Netherfield,”
said Mrs. Bennet to her husband, “and all the others equally well
married, I shall have nothing to wish for.”

In a few days Mr. Bingley returned Mr. Bennet’s visit, and sat about ten
minutes with him in his library.
Label: jane

Text:
He had entertained hopes of being
admitted to a sight of the young ladies, of whose beauty he had heard
much; but he saw only the father.
Label: jane

Text:
The ladies were somewhat more
fortunate, for they had the advantage of ascertaining, from an upper
window, that he wore a blue coat and rode a black horse.
Label: jane

Text:
An invitation to dinner was soon afterwards despatched; and already had
Mrs. Bennet planned the courses that were to do credit to her
housekeeping, when an answer arrived which deferred it all.
Label: jane

Text:
Mr. Bingley
was obliged to be in town the following day, and consequently unable to
accept the honour of their invitation, etc.
Label: jane

Text:
Mrs. Bennet was quite
disconcerted.
Label: jane

Text:
She could not imagine what business he could have in town
so soon after his arrival in Hertfordshire; and she began to fear that
he might always be flying about from one place to another, and never
settled at Netherfield as he ought to be.
Label: jane

Text:
Lady Lucas quieted her fears a
little by starting the idea of his

[Illustration:

     “When the Party entered”

[_Copyright 1894 by George Allen._]]

being gone to London only to get a large party for the ball; and a
report soon followed that Mr. Bingley was to bring twelve ladies and
seven gentlemen with him to the assembly.
Label: jane

Text:
The girls grieved over such a
number of ladies; but were comforted the day before the ball by hearing
that, instead of twelve, he had brought only six with him from London,
his five sisters and a cousin.
Label: jane

Text:
And when the party entered the
assembly-room, it consisted of only five altogether: Mr. Bingley, his
two sisters, the husband of the eldest, and another young man.
Label: jane

Text:
Mr. Bingley was good-looking and gentlemanlike: he had a pleasant
countenance, and easy, unaffected manners.
Label: jane

Text:
His sisters were fine women,
with an air of decided fashion.
Label: jane

Text:
His brother-in-law, Mr. Hurst, merely
looked the gentleman; but his friend Mr. Darcy soon drew the attention
of the room by his fine, tall person, handsome features, noble mien, and
the report, which was in general circulation within five minutes after
his entrance, of his having ten thousand a year.
Label: jane

Text:
The gentlemen
pronounced him to be a fine figure of a man, the ladies declared he was
much handsomer than Mr. Bingley, and he was looked at with great
admiration for about half the evening, till his manners gave a disgust
which turned the tide of his popularity; for he was discovered to be
proud, to be above his company, and above being pleased; and not all his
large estate in Derbyshire could save him from having a most forbidding,
disagreeable countenance, and being unworthy to be compared with his
friend.
Label: jane

Text:
Mr. Bingley had soon made himself acquainted with all the principal
people in the room: he was lively and unreserved, danced every dance,
was angry that the ball closed so early, and talked of giving one
himself at Netherfield.
Label: jane

Text:
Such amiable qualities must speak for
themselves.
Label: jane

Text: What a contrast between him and his friend!
Label: jane

Text:
Mr. Darcy danced
only once with Mrs. Hurst and once with Miss Bingley, declined being
introduced to any other lady, and spent the rest of the evening in
walking about the room, speaking occasionally to one of his own party.
Label: jane

Text: His character was decided.
Label: jane

Text:
He was the proudest, most disagreeable man in
the world, and everybody hoped that he would never come there again.
Label: jane

Text:
Amongst the most violent against him was Mrs. Bennet, whose dislike of
his general behaviour was sharpened into particular resentment by his
having slighted one of her daughters.
Label: jane

Text:
Elizabeth Bennet had been obliged, by the scarcity of gentlemen, to sit
down for two dances; and during part of that time, Mr. Darcy had been
standing near enough for her to overhear a conversation between him and
Mr. Bingley, who came from the dance for a few minutes to press his
friend to join it.
Label: jane

Text: “Come, Darcy,” said he, “I must have you dance.
Label: jane

Text:
I hate to see you
standing about by yourself in this stupid manner.
Label: jane

Text:
You had much better
dance.”

“I certainly shall not.
Label: jane

Text:
You know how I detest it, unless I am
particularly acquainted with my partner.
Label: jane

Text:
At such an assembly as this, it
would be insupportable.
Label: jane

Text:
Your sisters are engaged, and there is not
another woman in the room whom it would not be a punishment to me to
stand up with.”

“I would not be so fastidious as you are,” cried Bingley, “for a
kingdom!
Label: jane

Text:
Upon my honour, I never met with so many pleasant girls in my
life as I have this evening; and there are several of them, you see,
uncommonly pretty.”

“_You_ are dancing with the only handsome girl in the room,” said Mr.
Darcy, looking at the eldest Miss Bennet.
Label: jane

Text: “Oh, she is the most beautiful creature I ever beheld!
Label: jane

Text:
But there is one
of her sisters sitting down just behind you, who is very pretty, and I
dare say very agreeable.
Label: jane

Text:
Do let me ask my partner to introduce you.”

[Illustration:

“She is tolerable”

[_Copyright 1894 by George Allen._]]

“Which do you mean?” and turning round, he looked for a moment at
Elizabeth, till, catching her eye, he withdrew his own, and coldly said,
“She is tolerable: but not handsome enough to tempt _me_; and I am in no
humour at present to give consequence to young ladies who are slighted
by other men.
Label: jane

Text:
You had better return to your partner and enjoy her
smiles, for you are wasting your time with me.”

Mr. Bingley followed his advice.
Label: jane

Text:
Mr. Darcy walked off; and Elizabeth
remained with no very cordial feelings towards him.
Label: jane

Text:
She told the story,
however, with great spirit among her friends; for she had a lively,
playful disposition, which delighted in anything ridiculous.
Label: jane

Text: The evening altogether passed off pleasantly to the whole family.
Label: jane

Text:
Mrs.
Bennet had seen her eldest daughter much admired by the Netherfield
party.
Label: jane

Text:
Mr. Bingley had danced with her twice, and she had been
distinguished by his sisters.
Label: jane

Text:
Jane was as much gratified by this as her
mother could be, though in a quieter way.
Label: jane

Text:
Elizabeth felt Jane’s
pleasure.
Label: jane

Text:
Mary had heard herself mentioned to Miss Bingley as the most
accomplished girl in the neighbourhood; and Catherine and Lydia had been
fortunate enough to be never without partners, which was all that they
had yet learnt to care for at a ball.
Label: jane

Text:
They returned, therefore, in good
spirits to Longbourn, the village where they lived, and of which they
were the principal inhabitants.
Label: jane

Text: They found Mr. Bennet still up.
Label: jane

Text:
With a
book, he was regardless of time; and on the present occasion he had a
good deal of curiosity as to the event of an evening which had raised
such splendid expectations.
Label: jane

Text:
He had rather hoped that all his wife’s
views on the stranger would be disappointed; but he soon found that he
had a very different story to hear.
Label: jane

Text:
“Oh, my dear Mr. Bennet,” as she entered the room, “we have had a most
delightful evening, a most excellent ball.
Label: jane

Text: I wish you had been there.
Label: jane

Text: Jane was so admired, nothing could be like it.
Label: jane

Text:
Everybody said how well
she looked; and Mr. Bingley thought her quite beautiful, and danced with
her twice.
Label: jane

Text:
Only think of _that_, my dear: he actually danced with her
twice; and she was the only creature in the room that he asked a second
time.
Label: jane

Text: First of all, he asked Miss Lucas.
Label: jane

Text:
I was so vexed to see him stand
up with her; but, however, he did not admire her at all; indeed, nobody
can, you know; and he seemed quite struck with Jane as she was going
down the dance.
Label: jane

Text:
So he inquired who she was, and got introduced, and
asked her for the two next.
Label: jane

Text:
Then, the two third he danced with Miss
King, and the two fourth with Maria Lucas, and the two fifth with Jane
again, and the two sixth with Lizzy, and the _Boulanger_----”

“If he had had any compassion for _me_,” cried her husband impatiently,
“he would not have danced half so much!
Label: jane

Text:
For God’s sake, say no more of
his partners.
Label: jane

Text:
O that he had sprained his ancle in the first dance!”

“Oh, my dear,” continued Mrs. Bennet, “I am quite delighted with him.
Label: jane

Text:
He
is so excessively handsome!
Label: jane

Text: and his sisters are charming women.
Label: jane

Text:
I never
in my life saw anything more elegant than their dresses.
Label: jane

Text:
I dare say the
lace upon Mrs. Hurst’s gown----”

Here she was interrupted again.
Label: jane

Text:
Mr. Bennet protested against any
description of finery.
Label: jane

Text:
She was therefore obliged to seek another branch
of the subject, and related, with much bitterness of spirit, and some
exaggeration, the shocking rudeness of Mr. Darcy.
Label: jane

Text:
“But I can assure you,” she added, “that Lizzy does not lose much by not
suiting _his_ fancy; for he is a most disagreeable, horrid man, not at
all worth pleasing.
Label: jane

Text:
So high and so conceited, that there was no enduring
him!
Label: jane

Text:
He walked here, and he walked there, fancying himself so very
great!
Label: jane

Text: Not handsome enough to dance with!
Label: jane

Text:
I wish you had been there, my
dear, to have given him one of your set-downs.
Label: jane

Text:
I quite detest the man.”




[Illustration]




CHAPTER IV.
Label: jane

Text:
[Illustration]

When Jane and Elizabeth were alone, the former, who had been cautious in
her praise of Mr. Bingley before, expressed to her sister how very much
she admired him.
Label: jane

Text:
“He is just what a young-man ought to be,” said she, “sensible,
good-humoured, lively; and I never saw such happy manners!
Label: jane

Text:
so much ease,
with such perfect good breeding!”

“He is also handsome,” replied Elizabeth, “which a young man ought
likewise to be if he possibly can.
Label: jane

Text:
His character is thereby complete.”

“I was very much flattered by his asking me to dance a second time.
Label: jane

Text:
I
did not expect such a compliment.”

“Did not you?
Label: jane

Text: _I_ did for you.
Label: jane

Text:
But that is one great difference between
us.
Label: jane

Text: Compliments always take _you_ by surprise, and _me_ never.
Label: jane

Text:
What
could be more natural than his asking you again?
Label: jane

Text:
He could not help
seeing that you were about five times as pretty as every other woman in
the room.
Label: jane

Text: No thanks to his gallantry for that.
Label: jane

Text:
Well, he certainly is
very agreeable, and I give you leave to like him.
Label: jane

Text:
You have liked many a
stupider person.”

“Dear Lizzy!”

“Oh, you are a great deal too apt, you know, to like people in general.
Label: jane

Text: You never see a fault in anybody.
Label: jane

Text:
All the world are good and agreeable
in your eyes.
Label: jane

Text:
I never heard you speak ill of a human being in my life.”

“I would wish not to be hasty in censuring anyone; but I always speak
what I think.”

“I know you do: and it is _that_ which makes the wonder.
Label: jane

Text:
With _your_
good sense, to be so honestly blind to the follies and nonsense of
others!
Label: jane

Text:
Affectation of candour is common enough; one meets with it
everywhere.
Label: jane

Text:
But to be candid without ostentation or design,--to take the
good of everybody’s character and make it still better, and say nothing
of the bad,--belongs to you alone.
Label: jane

Text:
And so, you like this man’s sisters,
too, do you?
Label: jane

Text:
Their manners are not equal to his.”

“Certainly not, at first; but they are very pleasing women when you
converse with them.
Label: jane

Text:
Miss Bingley is to live with her brother, and keep
his house; and I am much mistaken if we shall not find a very charming
neighbour in her.”

Elizabeth listened in silence, but was not convinced: their behaviour at
the assembly had not been calculated to please in general; and with more
quickness of observation and less pliancy of temper than her sister, and
with a judgment, too, unassailed by any attention to herself, she was
very little disposed to approve them.
Label: jane

Text:
They were, in fact, very fine
ladies; not deficient in good-humour when they were pleased, nor in the
power of being agreeable where they chose it; but proud and conceited.
Label: jane

Text:
They were rather handsome; had been educated in one of the first private
seminaries in town; had a fortune of twenty thousand pounds; were in the
habit of spending more than they ought, and of associating with people
of rank; and were, therefore, in every respect entitled to think well of
themselves and meanly of others.
Label: jane

Text:
They were of a respectable family in
the north of England; a circumstance more deeply impressed on their
memories than that their brother’s fortune and their own had been
acquired by trade.
Label: jane

Text:
Mr. Bingley inherited property to the amount of nearly a hundred
thousand pounds from his father, who had intended to purchase an estate,
but did not live to do it.
Label: jane

Text:
Mr. Bingley intended it likewise, and
sometimes made choice of his county; but, as he was now provided with a
good house and the liberty of a manor, it was doubtful to many of those
who best knew the easiness of his temper, whether he might not spend the
remainder of his days at Netherfield, and leave the next generation to
purchase.
Label: jane

Text:
His sisters were very anxious for his having an estate of his own; but
though he was now established only as a tenant, Miss Bingley was by no
means unwilling to preside at his table; nor was Mrs. Hurst, who had
married a man of more fashion than fortune, less disposed to consider
his house as her home when it suited her.
Label: jane

Text:
Mr. Bingley had not been of
age two years when he was tempted, by an accidental recommendation, to
look at Netherfield House.
Label: jane

Text:
He did look at it, and into it, for half an
hour; was pleased with the situation and the principal rooms, satisfied
with what the owner said in its praise, and took it immediately.
Label: jane

Text:
Between him and Darcy there was a very steady friendship, in spite of a
great opposition of character.
Label: jane

Text:
Bingley was endeared to Darcy by the
easiness, openness, and ductility of his temper, though no disposition
could offer a greater contrast to his own, and though with his own he
never appeared dissatisfied.
Label: jane

Text:
On the strength of Darcy’s regard, Bingley
had the firmest reliance, and of his judgment the highest opinion.
Label: jane

Text:
In
understanding, Darcy was the superior.
Label: jane

Text:
Bingley was by no means
deficient; but Darcy was clever.
Label: jane

Text:
He was at the same time haughty,
reserved, and fastidious; and his manners, though well bred, were not
inviting.
Label: jane

Text: In that respect his friend had greatly the advantage.
Label: jane

Text:
Bingley
was sure of being liked wherever he appeared; Darcy was continually
giving offence.
Label: jane

Text:
The manner in which they spoke of the Meryton assembly was sufficiently
characteristic.
Label: jane

Text:
Bingley had never met with pleasanter people or prettier
girls in his life; everybody had been most kind and attentive to him;
there had been no formality, no stiffness; he had soon felt acquainted
with all the room; and as to Miss Bennet, he could not conceive an angel
more beautiful.
Label: jane

Text:
Darcy, on the contrary, had seen a collection of people
in whom there was little beauty and no fashion, for none of whom he had
felt the smallest interest, and from none received either attention or
pleasure.
Label: jane

Text:
Miss Bennet he acknowledged to be pretty; but she smiled too
much.
Label: jane

Text:
Mrs. Hurst and her sister allowed it to be so; but still they admired
her and liked her, and pronounced her to be a sweet girl, and one whom
they should not object to know more of.
Label: jane

Text:
Miss Bennet was therefore
established as a sweet girl; and their brother felt authorized by such
commendation to think of her as he chose.
Label: jane

Text:
[Illustration: [_Copyright 1894 by George Allen._]]




CHAPTER V.


[Illustration]

Within a short walk of Longbourn lived a family with whom the Bennets
were particularly intimate.
Label: jane

Text:
Sir William Lucas had been formerly in trade
in Meryton, where he had made a tolerable fortune, and risen to the
honour of knighthood by an address to the king during his mayoralty.
Label: jane

Text:
The
distinction had, perhaps, been felt too strongly.
Label: jane

Text:
It had given him a
disgust to his business and to his residence in a small market town;
and, quitting them both, he had removed with his family to a house about
a mile from Meryton, denominated from that period Lucas Lodge; where he
could think with pleasure of his own importance, and, unshackled by
business, occupy himself solely in being civil to all the world.
Label: jane

Text:
For,
though elated by his rank, it did not render him supercilious; on the
contrary, he was all attention to everybody.
Label: jane

Text:
By nature inoffensive,
friendly, and obliging, his presentation at St. James’s had made him
courteous.
Label: jane

Text:
Lady Lucas was a very good kind of woman, not too clever to be a
valuable neighbour to Mrs. Bennet.
Label: jane

Text: They had several children.
Label: jane

Text:
The eldest
of them, a sensible, intelligent young woman, about twenty-seven, was
Elizabeth’s intimate friend.
Label: jane

Text:
That the Miss Lucases and the Miss Bennets should meet to talk over a
ball was absolutely necessary; and the morning after the assembly
brought the former to Longbourn to hear and to communicate.
Label: jane

Text:
“_You_ began the evening well, Charlotte,” said Mrs. Bennet, with civil
self-command, to Miss Lucas.
Label: jane

Text:
“_You_ were Mr. Bingley’s first choice.”

“Yes; but he seemed to like his second better.”

“Oh, you mean Jane, I suppose, because he danced with her twice.
Label: jane

Text:
To be
sure that _did_ seem as if he admired her--indeed, I rather believe he
_did_--I heard something about it--but I hardly know what--something
about Mr. Robinson.”

“Perhaps you mean what I overheard between him and Mr. Robinson: did not
I mention it to you?
Label: jane

Text:
Mr. Robinson’s asking him how he liked our Meryton
assemblies, and whether he did not think there were a great many pretty
women in the room, and _which_ he thought the prettiest?
Label: jane

Text: ﻿CHAPTER I.
Label: jane

Text: The family of Dashwood had long been settled in Sussex.
Label: jane

Text:
Their estate
was large, and their residence was at Norland Park, in the centre of
their property, where, for many generations, they had lived in so
respectable a manner as to engage the general good opinion of their
surrounding acquaintance.
Label: jane

Text:
The late owner of this estate was a single
man, who lived to a very advanced age, and who for many years of his
life, had a constant companion and housekeeper in his sister.
Label: jane

Text:
But her
death, which happened ten years before his own, produced a great
alteration in his home; for to supply her loss, he invited and received
into his house the family of his nephew Mr. Henry Dashwood, the legal
inheritor of the Norland estate, and the person to whom he intended to
bequeath it.
Label: jane

Text:
In the society of his nephew and niece, and their
children, the old Gentleman’s days were comfortably spent.
Label: jane

Text:
His
attachment to them all increased.
Label: jane

Text:
The constant attention of Mr. and
Mrs. Henry Dashwood to his wishes, which proceeded not merely from
interest, but from goodness of heart, gave him every degree of solid
comfort which his age could receive; and the cheerfulness of the
children added a relish to his existence.
Label: jane

Text:
By a former marriage, Mr. Henry Dashwood had one son: by his present
lady, three daughters.
Label: jane

Text:
The son, a steady respectable young man, was
amply provided for by the fortune of his mother, which had been large,
and half of which devolved on him on his coming of age.
Label: jane

Text:
By his own
marriage, likewise, which happened soon afterwards, he added to his
wealth.
Label: jane

Text:
To him therefore the succession to the Norland estate was not
so really important as to his sisters; for their fortune, independent
of what might arise to them from their father’s inheriting that
property, could be but small.
Label: jane

Text:
Their mother had nothing, and their
father only seven thousand pounds in his own disposal; for the
remaining moiety of his first wife’s fortune was also secured to her
child, and he had only a life-interest in it.
Label: jane

Text:
The old gentleman died: his will was read, and like almost every other
will, gave as much disappointment as pleasure.
Label: jane

Text:
He was neither so
unjust, nor so ungrateful, as to leave his estate from his nephew;—but
he left it to him on such terms as destroyed half the value of the
bequest.
Label: jane

Text:
Mr. Dashwood had wished for it more for the sake of his wife
and daughters than for himself or his son;—but to his son, and his
son’s son, a child of four years old, it was secured, in such a way, as
to leave to himself no power of providing for those who were most dear
to him, and who most needed a provision by any charge on the estate, or
by any sale of its valuable woods.
Label: jane

Text:
The whole was tied up for the
benefit of this child, who, in occasional visits with his father and
mother at Norland, had so far gained on the affections of his uncle, by
such attractions as are by no means unusual in children of two or three
years old; an imperfect articulation, an earnest desire of having his
own way, many cunning tricks, and a great deal of noise, as to outweigh
all the value of all the attention which, for years, he had received
from his niece and her daughters.
Label: jane

Text:
He meant not to be unkind, however,
and, as a mark of his affection for the three girls, he left them a
thousand pounds a-piece.
Label: jane

Text:
Mr. Dashwood’s disappointment was, at first, severe; but his temper was
cheerful and sanguine; and he might reasonably hope to live many years,
and by living economically, lay by a considerable sum from the produce
of an estate already large, and capable of almost immediate
improvement.
Label: jane

Text:
But the fortune, which had been so tardy in coming, was
his only one twelvemonth.
Label: jane

Text:
He survived his uncle no longer; and ten
thousand pounds, including the late legacies, was all that remained for
his widow and daughters.
Label: jane

Text:
His son was sent for as soon as his danger was known, and to him Mr.
Dashwood recommended, with all the strength and urgency which illness
could command, the interest of his mother-in-law and sisters.
Label: jane

Text:
Mr. John Dashwood had not the strong feelings of the rest of the
family; but he was affected by a recommendation of such a nature at
such a time, and he promised to do every thing in his power to make
them comfortable.
Label: jane

Text:
His father was rendered easy by such an assurance,
and Mr. John Dashwood had then leisure to consider how much there might
prudently be in his power to do for them.
Label: jane

Text:
He was not an ill-disposed young man, unless to be rather cold hearted
and rather selfish is to be ill-disposed: but he was, in general, well
respected; for he conducted himself with propriety in the discharge of
his ordinary duties.
Label: jane

Text:
Had he married a more amiable woman, he might have
been made still more respectable than he was:—he might even have been
made amiable himself; for he was very young when he married, and very
fond of his wife.
Label: jane

Text:
But Mrs. John Dashwood was a strong caricature of
himself;—more narrow-minded and selfish.
Label: jane

Text:
When he gave his promise to his father, he meditated within himself to
increase the fortunes of his sisters by the present of a thousand
pounds a-piece.
Label: jane

Text: He then really thought himself equal to it.
Label: jane

Text:
The
prospect of four thousand a-year, in addition to his present income,
besides the remaining half of his own mother’s fortune, warmed his
heart, and made him feel capable of generosity.
Label: jane

Text:
“Yes, he would give
them three thousand pounds: it would be liberal and handsome!
Label: jane

Text:
It would
be enough to make them completely easy.
Label: jane

Text: Three thousand pounds!
Label: jane

Text:
he could
spare so considerable a sum with little inconvenience.” He thought of
it all day long, and for many days successively, and he did not repent.
Label: jane

Text:
No sooner was his father’s funeral over, than Mrs. John Dashwood,
without sending any notice of her intention to her mother-in-law,
arrived with her child and their attendants.
Label: jane

Text:
No one could dispute her
right to come; the house was her husband’s from the moment of his
father’s decease; but the indelicacy of her conduct was so much the
greater, and to a woman in Mrs. Dashwood’s situation, with only common
feelings, must have been highly unpleasing;—but in _her_ mind there was
a sense of honor so keen, a generosity so romantic, that any offence of
the kind, by whomsoever given or received, was to her a source of
immovable disgust.
Label: jane

Text:
Mrs. John Dashwood had never been a favourite with
any of her husband’s family; but she had had no opportunity, till the
present, of showing them with how little attention to the comfort of
other people she could act when occasion required it.
Label: jane

Text:
So acutely did Mrs. Dashwood feel this ungracious behaviour, and so
earnestly did she despise her daughter-in-law for it, that, on the
arrival of the latter, she would have quitted the house for ever, had
not the entreaty of her eldest girl induced her first to reflect on the
propriety of going, and her own tender love for all her three children
determined her afterwards to stay, and for their sakes avoid a breach
with their brother.
Label: jane

Text:
Elinor, this eldest daughter, whose advice was so effectual, possessed
a strength of understanding, and coolness of judgment, which qualified
her, though only nineteen, to be the counsellor of her mother, and
enabled her frequently to counteract, to the advantage of them all,
that eagerness of mind in Mrs. Dashwood which must generally have led
to imprudence.
Label: jane

Text:
She had an excellent heart;—her disposition was
affectionate, and her feelings were strong; but she knew how to govern
them: it was a knowledge which her mother had yet to learn; and which
one of her sisters had resolved never to be taught.
Label: jane

Text: Marianne’s abilities were, in many respects, quite equal to Elinor’s.
Label: jane

Text:
She was sensible and clever; but eager in everything: her sorrows, her
joys, could have no moderation.
Label: jane

Text:
She was generous, amiable, interesting:
she was everything but prudent.
Label: jane

Text:
The resemblance between her and her
mother was strikingly great.
Label: jane

Text:
Elinor saw, with concern, the excess of her sister’s sensibility; but
by Mrs. Dashwood it was valued and cherished.
Label: jane

Text:
They encouraged each
other now in the violence of their affliction.
Label: jane

Text:
The agony of grief which
overpowered them at first, was voluntarily renewed, was sought for, was
created again and again.
Label: jane

Text:
They gave themselves up wholly to their
sorrow, seeking increase of wretchedness in every reflection that could
afford it, and resolved against ever admitting consolation in future.
Label: jane

Text:
Elinor, too, was deeply afflicted; but still she could struggle, she
could exert herself.
Label: jane

Text:
She could consult with her brother, could receive
her sister-in-law on her arrival, and treat her with proper attention;
and could strive to rouse her mother to similar exertion, and encourage
her to similar forbearance.
Label: jane

Text:
Margaret, the other sister, was a good-humored, well-disposed girl; but
as she had already imbibed a good deal of Marianne’s romance, without
having much of her sense, she did not, at thirteen, bid fair to equal
her sisters at a more advanced period of life.
Label: jane

Text: CHAPTER II.
Label: jane

Text:
Mrs. John Dashwood now installed herself mistress of Norland; and her
mother and sisters-in-law were degraded to the condition of visitors.
Label: jane

Text:
As such, however, they were treated by her with quiet civility; and by
her husband with as much kindness as he could feel towards anybody
beyond himself, his wife, and their child.
Label: jane

Text:
He really pressed them, with
some earnestness, to consider Norland as their home; and, as no plan
appeared so eligible to Mrs. Dashwood as remaining there till she could
accommodate herself with a house in the neighbourhood, his invitation
was accepted.
Label: jane

Text:
A continuance in a place where everything reminded her of former
delight, was exactly what suited her mind.
Label: jane

Text:
In seasons of cheerfulness,
no temper could be more cheerful than hers, or possess, in a greater
degree, that sanguine expectation of happiness which is happiness
itself.
Label: jane

Text:
But in sorrow she must be equally carried away by her fancy,
and as far beyond consolation as in pleasure she was beyond alloy.
Label: jane

Text:
Mrs. John Dashwood did not at all approve of what her husband intended
to do for his sisters.
Label: jane

Text:
To take three thousand pounds from the fortune
of their dear little boy would be impoverishing him to the most
dreadful degree.
Label: jane

Text: She begged him to think again on the subject.
Label: jane

Text:
How
could he answer it to himself to rob his child, and his only child too,
of so large a sum?
Label: jane

Text:
And what possible claim could the Miss Dashwoods,
who were related to him only by half blood, which she considered as no
relationship at all, have on his generosity to so large an amount.
Label: jane

Text:
It
was very well known that no affection was ever supposed to exist
between the children of any man by different marriages; and why was he
to ruin himself, and their poor little Harry, by giving away all his
money to his half sisters?
Label: jane

Text:
“It was my father’s last request to me,” replied her husband, “that I
should assist his widow and daughters.”

“He did not know what he was talking of, I dare say; ten to one but he
was light-headed at the time.
Label: jane

Text:
Had he been in his right senses, he could
not have thought of such a thing as begging you to give away half your
fortune from your own child.”

“He did not stipulate for any particular sum, my dear Fanny; he only
requested me, in general terms, to assist them, and make their
situation more comfortable than it was in his power to do.
Label: jane

Text:
Perhaps it
would have been as well if he had left it wholly to myself.
Label: jane

Text:
He could
hardly suppose I should neglect them.
Label: jane

Text:
But as he required the promise, I
could not do less than give it; at least I thought so at the time.
Label: jane

Text:
The
promise, therefore, was given, and must be performed.
Label: jane

Text:
Something must be
done for them whenever they leave Norland and settle in a new home.”

“Well, then, _let_ something be done for them; but _that_ something
need not be three thousand pounds.
Label: jane

Text:
Consider,” she added, “that when the
money is once parted with, it never can return.
Label: jane

Text:
Your sisters will
marry, and it will be gone for ever.
Label: jane

Text:
If, indeed, it could be restored
to our poor little boy—”

“Why, to be sure,” said her husband, very gravely, “that would make
great difference.
Label: jane

Text:
The time may come when Harry will regret that so
large a sum was parted with.
Label: jane

Text:
If he should have a numerous family, for
instance, it would be a very convenient addition.”

“To be sure it would.”

“Perhaps, then, it would be better for all parties, if the sum were
diminished one half.—Five hundred pounds would be a prodigious increase
to their fortunes!”

“Oh!
Label: jane

Text: beyond anything great!
Label: jane

Text:
What brother on earth would do half so much
for his sisters, even if _really_ his sisters!
Label: jane

Text:
And as it is—only half
blood!—But you have such a generous spirit!”

“I would not wish to do any thing mean,” he replied.
Label: jane

Text:
“One had rather,
on such occasions, do too much than too little.
Label: jane

Text:
No one, at least, can
think I have not done enough for them: even themselves, they can hardly
expect more.”

“There is no knowing what _they_ may expect,” said the lady, “but we
are not to think of their expectations: the question is, what you can
afford to do.”

“Certainly—and I think I may afford to give them five hundred pounds
a-piece.
Label: jane

Text:
As it is, without any addition of mine, they will each have
about three thousand pounds on their mother’s death—a very comfortable
fortune for any young woman.”

“To be sure it is; and, indeed, it strikes me that they can want no
addition at all.
Label: jane

Text:
They will have ten thousand pounds divided amongst
them.
Label: jane

Text:
If they marry, they will be sure of doing well, and if they do
not, they may all live very comfortably together on the interest of ten
thousand pounds.”

“That is very true, and, therefore, I do not know whether, upon the
whole, it would not be more advisable to do something for their mother
while she lives, rather than for them—something of the annuity kind I
mean.—My sisters would feel the good effects of it as well as herself.
Label: jane

Text:
A hundred a year would make them all perfectly comfortable.”

His wife hesitated a little, however, in giving her consent to this
plan.
Label: jane

Text:
“To be sure,” said she, “it is better than parting with fifteen hundred
pounds at once.
Label: jane

Text:
But, then, if Mrs. Dashwood should live fifteen years
we shall be completely taken in.”

“Fifteen years!
Label: jane

Text:
my dear Fanny; her life cannot be worth half that
purchase.”

“Certainly not; but if you observe, people always live for ever when
there is an annuity to be paid them; and she is very stout and healthy,
and hardly forty.
Label: jane

Text:
An annuity is a very serious business; it comes over
and over every year, and there is no getting rid of it.
Label: jane

Text:
You are not
aware of what you are doing.
Label: jane

Text:
I have known a great deal of the trouble
of annuities; for my mother was clogged with the payment of three to
old superannuated servants by my father’s will, and it is amazing how
disagreeable she found it.
Label: jane

Text:
Twice every year these annuities were to be
paid; and then there was the trouble of getting it to them; and then
one of them was said to have died, and afterwards it turned out to be
no such thing.
Label: jane

Text: My mother was quite sick of it.
Label: jane

Text:
Her income was not her
own, she said, with such perpetual claims on it; and it was the more
unkind in my father, because, otherwise, the money would have been
entirely at my mother’s disposal, without any restriction whatever.
Label: jane

Text:
It
has given me such an abhorrence of annuities, that I am sure I would
not pin myself down to the payment of one for all the world.”

“It is certainly an unpleasant thing,” replied Mr. Dashwood, “to have
those kind of yearly drains on one’s income.
Label: jane

Text:
One’s fortune, as your
mother justly says, is _not_ one’s own.
Label: jane

Text:
To be tied down to the regular
payment of such a sum, on every rent day, is by no means desirable: it
takes away one’s independence.”

“Undoubtedly; and after all you have no thanks for it.
Label: jane

Text:
They think
themselves secure, you do no more than what is expected, and it raises
no gratitude at all.
Label: jane

Text:
If I were you, whatever I did should be done at my
own discretion entirely.
Label: jane

Text:
I would not bind myself to allow them any
thing yearly.
Label: jane

Text:
It may be very inconvenient some years to spare a
hundred, or even fifty pounds from our own expenses.”

“I believe you are right, my love; it will be better that there should
be no annuity in the case; whatever I may give them occasionally will
be of far greater assistance than a yearly allowance, because they
would only enlarge their style of living if they felt sure of a larger
income, and would not be sixpence the richer for it at the end of the
year.
Label: jane

Text: It will certainly be much the best way.
Label: jane

Text:
A present of fifty
pounds, now and then, will prevent their ever being distressed for
money, and will, I think, be amply discharging my promise to my
father.”

“To be sure it will.
Label: jane

Text:
Indeed, to say the truth, I am convinced within
myself that your father had no idea of your giving them any money at
all.
Label: jane

Text:
The assistance he thought of, I dare say, was only such as might
be reasonably expected of you; for instance, such as looking out for a
comfortable small house for them, helping them to move their things,
and sending them presents of fish and game, and so forth, whenever they
are in season.
Label: jane

Text:
I’ll lay my life that he meant nothing farther; indeed,
it would be very strange and unreasonable if he did.
Label: jane

Text:
Do but consider,
my dear Mr. Dashwood, how excessively comfortable your mother-in-law
and her daughters may live on the interest of seven thousand pounds,
besides the thousand pounds belonging to each of the girls, which
brings them in fifty pounds a year a-piece, and, of course, they will
pay their mother for their board out of it.
Label: jane

Text:
Altogether, they will have
five hundred a-year amongst them, and what on earth can four women want
for more than that?—They will live so cheap!
Label: jane

Text:
Their housekeeping will be
nothing at all.
Label: jane

Text:
They will have no carriage, no horses, and hardly any
servants; they will keep no company, and can have no expenses of any
kind!
Label: jane

Text: Only conceive how comfortable they will be!
Label: jane

Text: Five hundred a year!
Label: jane

Text:
I am sure I cannot imagine how they will spend half of it; and as to
your giving them more, it is quite absurd to think of it.
Label: jane

Text:
They will be
much more able to give _you_ something.”

“Upon my word,” said Mr. Dashwood, “I believe you are perfectly right.
Label: jane

Text:
My father certainly could mean nothing more by his request to me than
what you say.
Label: jane

Text:
I clearly understand it now, and I will strictly fulfil
my engagement by such acts of assistance and kindness to them as you
have described.
Label: jane

Text:
When my mother removes into another house my services
shall be readily given to accommodate her as far as I can.
Label: jane

Text:
Some little
present of furniture too may be acceptable then.”

“Certainly,” returned Mrs. John Dashwood.
Label: jane

Text:
“But, however, _one_ thing
must be considered.
Label: jane

Text:
When your father and mother moved to Norland,
though the furniture of Stanhill was sold, all the china, plate, and
linen was saved, and is now left to your mother.
Label: jane

Text:
Her house will
therefore be almost completely fitted up as soon as she takes it.”

“That is a material consideration undoubtedly.
Label: jane

Text:
A valuable legacy
indeed!
Label: jane

Text:
And yet some of the plate would have been a very pleasant
addition to our own stock here.”

“Yes; and the set of breakfast china is twice as handsome as what
belongs to this house.
Label: jane

Text:
A great deal too handsome, in my opinion, for
any place _they_ can ever afford to live in.
Label: jane

Text: But, however, so it is.
Label: jane

Text: Your father thought only of _them_.
Label: jane

Text:
And I must say this: that you owe
no particular gratitude to him, nor attention to his wishes; for we
very well know that if he could, he would have left almost everything
in the world to _them_.”

This argument was irresistible.
Label: jane

Text:
It gave to his intentions whatever of
decision was wanting before; and he finally resolved, that it would be
absolutely unnecessary, if not highly indecorous, to do more for the
widow and children of his father, than such kind of neighbourly acts as
his own wife pointed out.
Label: jane

Text: CHAPTER III.
Label: jane

Text:
Mrs. Dashwood remained at Norland several months; not from any
disinclination to move when the sight of every well known spot ceased
to raise the violent emotion which it produced for a while; for when
her spirits began to revive, and her mind became capable of some other
exertion than that of heightening its affliction by melancholy
remembrances, she was impatient to be gone, and indefatigable in her
inquiries for a suitable dwelling in the neighbourhood of Norland; for
to remove far from that beloved spot was impossible.
Label: jane

Text:
But she could hear
of no situation that at once answered her notions of comfort and ease,
and suited the prudence of her eldest daughter, whose steadier judgment
rejected several houses as too large for their income, which her mother
would have approved.
Label: jane

Text:
Mrs. Dashwood had been informed by her husband of the solemn promise on
the part of his son in their favour, which gave comfort to his last
earthly reflections.
Label: jane

Text:
She doubted the sincerity of this assurance no
more than he had doubted it himself, and she thought of it for her
daughters’ sake with satisfaction, though as for herself she was
persuaded that a much smaller provision than 7000£ would support her in
affluence.
Label: jane

Text:
For their brother’s sake, too, for the sake of his own
heart, she rejoiced; and she reproached herself for being unjust to his
merit before, in believing him incapable of generosity.
Label: jane

Text:
His attentive
behaviour to herself and his sisters convinced her that their welfare
was dear to him, and, for a long time, she firmly relied on the
liberality of his intentions.
Label: jane

Text:
The contempt which she had, very early in their acquaintance, felt for
her daughter-in-law, was very much increased by the farther knowledge
of her character, which half a year’s residence in her family afforded;
and perhaps in spite of every consideration of politeness or maternal
affection on the side of the former, the two ladies might have found it
impossible to have lived together so long, had not a particular
circumstance occurred to give still greater eligibility, according to
the opinions of Mrs. Dashwood, to her daughters’ continuance at
Norland.
Label: jane

Text:
This circumstance was a growing attachment between her eldest girl and
the brother of Mrs. John Dashwood, a gentleman-like and pleasing young
man, who was introduced to their acquaintance soon after his sister’s
establishment at Norland, and who had since spent the greatest part of
his time there.
Label: jane

Text:
Some mothers might have encouraged the intimacy from motives of
interest, for Edward Ferrars was the eldest son of a man who had died
very rich; and some might have repressed it from motives of prudence,
for, except a trifling sum, the whole of his fortune depended on the
will of his mother.
Label: jane

Text:
But Mrs. Dashwood was alike uninfluenced by either
consideration.
Label: jane

Text:
It was enough for her that he appeared to be amiable,
that he loved her daughter, and that Elinor returned the partiality.
Label: jane

Text:
It
was contrary to every doctrine of hers that difference of fortune
should keep any couple asunder who were attracted by resemblance of
disposition; and that Elinor’s merit should not be acknowledged by
every one who knew her, was to her comprehension impossible.
Label: jane

Text:
Edward Ferrars was not recommended to their good opinion by any
peculiar graces of person or address.
Label: jane

Text:
He was not handsome, and his
manners required intimacy to make them pleasing.
Label: jane

Text:
He was too diffident
to do justice to himself; but when his natural shyness was overcome,
his behaviour gave every indication of an open, affectionate heart.
Label: jane

Text:
His
understanding was good, and his education had given it solid
improvement.
Label: jane

Text:
But he was neither fitted by abilities nor disposition to
answer the wishes of his mother and sister, who longed to see him
distinguished—as—they hardly knew what.
Label: jane

Text:
They wanted him to make a fine
figure in the world in some manner or other.
Label: jane

Text:
His mother wished to
interest him in political concerns, to get him into parliament, or to
see him connected with some of the great men of the day.
Label: jane

Text:
Mrs. John
Dashwood wished it likewise; but in the mean while, till one of these
superior blessings could be attained, it would have quieted her
ambition to see him driving a barouche.
Label: jane

Text:
But Edward had no turn for
great men or barouches.
Label: jane

Text:
All his wishes centered in domestic comfort and
the quiet of private life.
Label: jane

Text:
Fortunately he had a younger brother who was
more promising.
Label: jane

Text:
Edward had been staying several weeks in the house before he engaged
much of Mrs. Dashwood’s attention; for she was, at that time, in such
affliction as rendered her careless of surrounding objects.
Label: jane

Text:
She saw
only that he was quiet and unobtrusive, and she liked him for it.
Label: jane

Text:
He
did not disturb the wretchedness of her mind by ill-timed conversation.
Label: jane

Text:
She was first called to observe and approve him farther, by a
reflection which Elinor chanced one day to make on the difference
between him and his sister.
Label: jane

Text:
It was a contrast which recommended him
most forcibly to her mother.
Label: jane

Text: “It is enough,” said she; “to say that he is unlike Fanny is enough.
Label: jane

Text:
It
implies everything amiable.

Text:
I love him already.”

“I think you will like him,” said Elinor, “when you know more of him.”

“Like him!” replied her mother with a smile.
Label: jane

Text:
“I feel no sentiment of
approbation inferior to love.”

“You may esteem him.”

“I have never yet known what it was to separate esteem and love.”

Mrs. Dashwood now took pains to get acquainted with him.
Label: jane

Text:
Her manners
were attaching, and soon banished his reserve.
Label: jane

Text:
She speedily
comprehended all his merits; the persuasion of his regard for Elinor
perhaps assisted her penetration; but she really felt assured of his
worth: and even that quietness of manner, which militated against all
her established ideas of what a young man’s address ought to be, was no
longer uninteresting when she knew his heart to be warm and his temper
affectionate.
Label: jane

Text:
No sooner did she perceive any symptom of love in his behaviour to
Elinor, than she considered their serious attachment as certain, and
looked forward to their marriage as rapidly approaching.
Label: jane

Text:
“In a few months, my dear Marianne,” said she, “Elinor will, in all
probability be settled for life.
Label: jane

Text:
We shall miss her; but _she_ will be
happy.”

“Oh!
Label: jane

Text:
Mama, how shall we do without her?”

“My love, it will be scarcely a separation.
Label: jane

Text:
We shall live within a few
miles of each other, and shall meet every day of our lives.
Label: jane

Text:
You will
gain a brother, a real, affectionate brother.
Label: jane

Text:
I have the highest
opinion in the world of Edward’s heart.
Label: jane
jane

Text:
Edward
is very amiable, and I love him tenderly.
Label: jane

Text:
But yet—he is not the kind of
young man—there is something wanting—his figure is not striking; it has
none of that grace which I should expect in the man who could seriously
attach my sister.
Label: jane

Text:
His eyes want all that spirit, that fire, which at
once announce virtue and intelligence.
Label: jane

Text:
And besides all this, I am
afraid, Mama, he has no real taste.
Label: jane

Text:
Music seems scarcely to attract
him, and though he admires Elinor’s drawings very much, it is not the
admiration of a person who can understand their worth.
Label: jane

Text:
It is evident,
in spite of his frequent attention to her while she draws, that in fact
he knows nothing of the matter.
Label: jane

Text:
He admires as a lover, not as a
connoisseur.
Label: jane

Text: To satisfy me, those characters must be united.
Label: jane

Text:
I could
not be happy with a man whose taste did not in every point coincide
with my own.
Label: jane

Text:
He must enter into all my feelings; the same books, the
same music must charm us both.
Label: jane

Text: Oh!
Label: jane

Text:
mama, how spiritless, how tame was
Edward’s manner in reading to us last night!
Label: jane

Text:
I felt for my sister most
severely.
Label: jane

Text:
Yet she bore it with so much composure, she seemed scarcely
to notice it.
Label: jane

Label: jane
