indoors till some carters who had been refreshing themselves had
departed with their big two-wheeled carts, piled up high with empty
wine-casks, in the direction of Fréjus.
Label: joseph

Text:
The fact that they did not
remain for the night pleased Peyrol.
Label: joseph

Text:
He ate his bit of supper alone, in
silence, and with a gravity which intimidated the old woman who had
aroused in him the memory of his mother.
Label: joseph

Text:
Having finished his pipe and
obtained a bit of candle in a tin candlestick, Citizen Peyrol went
heavily upstairs to rejoin his luggage.
Label: joseph

Text:
The crazy staircase shook and
groaned under his feet as though he had been carrying a burden.
Label: joseph

Text:
The
first thing he did was to close the shutters most carefully as though he
had been afraid of a breath of night air.
Label: joseph

Text:
Next he bolted the door of the
room.
Label: joseph

Text:
Then sitting on the floor, with the candlestick standing before
him between his widely straggled legs, he began to undress, flinging off
his coat and dragging his shirt hastily over his head.
Label: joseph

Text:
The secret of
his heavy movements was disclosed then in the fact that he had been
wearing next his bare skin--like a pious penitent his hair-shirt--a sort
of waistcoat made of two thicknesses of old sail-cloth and stitched all
over in the manner of a quilt with tarred twine.
Label: joseph

Text:
Three horn buttons
closed it in front.
Label: joseph

Text:
He undid them, and after he had slipped off the two
shoulder-straps which prevented this strange garment from sagging down
on his hips he started rolling it up.
Label: joseph

Text:
Notwithstanding all his care there
were during this operation several faint chinks of some metal which
could not have been lead.
Label: joseph

Text:
His bare torso thrown backwards and sustained by his rigid big arms
heavily tattooed on the white skin above the elbows, Peyrol drew a long
breath into his broad chest with a pepper and salt pelt down the
breastbone.
Label: joseph

Text:
And not only was the breast of Citizen Peyrol relieved to
the fullest of its athletic capacity, but a change had also come over
his large physiognomy on which the expression of severe stolidity had
been simply the result of physical discomfort.
Label: joseph

Text:
It isn’t a trifle to have
to carry girt about your ribs and hung from your shoulders a mass of
mixed foreign coins equal to sixty or seventy thousand francs in hard
cash; while as to the paper money of the Republic, Peyrol had had
already enough experience of it to estimate the equivalent in cartloads.
Label: joseph

Text: A thousand of them.
Label: joseph

Text: Perhaps two thousand.
Label: joseph

Text:
Enough in any case to justify
his flight of fancy, while looking at the countryside in the light of
the sunset, that what he had on him would buy all that soil from which
he had sprung: houses, woods, vines, olives, vegetable gardens, rocks
and salt lagoons--in fact, the whole landscape, including the animals
in it.
Label: joseph

Text: But Peyrol did not care for the land at all.
Label: joseph

Text:
He did not want to
own any part of the solid earth for which he had no love.
Label: joseph

Text:
All he wanted
from it was a quiet nook, an obscure corner out of men’s sight where he
could dig a hole unobserved.
Label: joseph

Text: That would have to be done pretty soon, he thought.
Label: joseph

Text:
One could not live
for an indefinite number of days with a treasure strapped round one’s
chest.
Label: joseph

Text:
Meantime, an utter stranger in his native country the landing on
which was perhaps the biggest adventure in his adventurous life, he
threw his jacket over the rolled-up waistcoat and laid his head down on
it after extinguishing the candle.
Label: joseph

Text: The night was warm.
Label: joseph

Text:
The floor of the
room happened to be of planks, not of tiles.
Label: joseph

Text:
He was no stranger to that
sort of couch.
Label: joseph

Text:
With his cudgel laid ready at his hand Peyrol slept
soundly till the noises and the voices about the house and on the road
woke him up shortly after sunrise.
Label: joseph

Text:
He threw open the shutter, welcoming
the morning light and the morning breeze in the full enjoyment of
idleness which, to a seaman of his kind, is inseparable from the fact of
being on shore.
Label: joseph

Text:
There was nothing to trouble his thoughts; and though
his physiognomy was far from being vacant, it did not wear the aspect of
profound meditation.
Label: joseph

Text:
It had been by the merest accident that he had discovered during the
passage, in a secret recess within one of the lockers of his prize, two
bags of mixed coins: gold mohurs, Dutch ducats, Spanish pieces, English
guineas.
Label: joseph

Text:
After making that discovery he had suffered from no doubts
whatever.
Label: joseph

Text:
Loot, big or little, was a natural fact of his freebooter’s
life.
Label: joseph

Text:
And now when by the force of things he had become a master-gunner
of the Navy he was not going to give up his find to confounded landsmen,
mere sharks, hungry quill-drivers, who would put it in their own
pockets.
Label: joseph

Text:
As to imparting the intelligence to his crew (all bad
characters), he was much too wise to do anything of the kind.
Label: joseph

Text:
They would
not have been above cutting his throat.
Label: joseph

Text:
An old fighting sea-dog, a
Brother of the Coast, had more right to such plunder than anybody on
earth.
Label: joseph

Text:
So at odd times, while at sea, he had busied himself within the
privacy of his cabin in constructing the ingenious canvas waistcoat in
which he could take his treasure ashore secretly.
Label: joseph

Text:
It was bulky, but his
garments were of an ample cut, and no wretched customs-guard would dare
to lay hands on a successful prize-master going to the Port Admiral’s
offices to make his report.
Label: joseph

Text: The scheme had worked perfectly.
Label: joseph

Text:
He found,
however, that this secret garment, which was worth precisely its weight
in gold, tried his endurance more than he had expected.
Label: joseph

Text:
It wearied his
body and even depressed his spirits somewhat.
Label: joseph

Text:
It made him less active
and also less communicative.
Label: joseph

Text:
It reminded him all the time that he must
not get into trouble of any sort--keep clear of rows, of intimacies, of
promiscuous jollities.
Label: joseph

Text:
This was one of the reasons why he had been
anxious to get away from the town.
Label: joseph

Text:
Once, however, his head was laid on
his treasure he could sleep the sleep of the just.
Label: joseph

Text: Nevertheless in the morning he shrank from putting it on again.
Label: joseph

Text:
With a
mixture of sailor’s carelessness and of old-standing belief in his own
luck he simply stuffed the precious waistcoat up the flue of the empty
fireplace.
Label: joseph

Text: Then he dressed and had his breakfast.
Label: joseph

Text:
An hour later,
mounted on a hired mule, he started down the track as calmly as though
setting out to explore the mysteries of a desert island.
Label: joseph

Text:
His aim was the end of the peninsula which, advancing like a colossal
jetty into the sea, divides the picturesque roadstead of Hyères from the
headlands and curves of the coast forming the approaches of the Port of
Toulon.
Label: joseph

Text:
The path along which the sure-footed mule took him (for Peyrol,
once he had put its head the right way, made no attempt at steering)
descended rapidly to a plain of arid aspect, with the white gleams of
the Salins in the distance, bounded by bluish hills of no great
elevation.
Label: joseph

Text:
Soon all traces of human habitations disappeared from before
his roaming eyes.
Label: joseph

Text:
This part of his native country was more foreign to
him than the shores of the Mozambique Channel, the coral strands of
India, the forests of Madagascar.
Label: joseph

Text:
Before long he found himself on the
neck of the Giens peninsula, impregnated with salt and containing a blue
lagoon, particularly blue, darker and even more still than the expanses
of the sea to the right and left of it, from which it was separated by
narrow strips of land not a hundred yards wide in places.
Label: joseph

Text:
The track ran
indistinct, presenting no wheel-ruts, and with patches of efflorescent
salt as white as snow between the tufts of wiry grass and the
particularly dead-looking bushes.
Label: joseph

Text:
The whole neck of land was so low that
it seemed to have no more thickness than a sheet of paper laid on the
sea.
Label: joseph

Text:
Citizen Peyrol saw on the level of his eye, as if from a mere raft,
sails of various craft, some white and some brown, while before him his
native island of Porquerolles rose dull and solid beyond a wide strip of
water.
Label: joseph

Text:
The mule, which knew rather better than Citizen Peyrol where it
was going to, took him presently amongst the gentle rises at the end of
the peninsula.
Label: joseph

Text:
The slopes were covered with scanty grass; crooked
boundary walls of dry stones ran across the fields, and above them, here
and there, peeped a low roof of red tiles shaded by the heads of
delicate acacias.
Label: joseph

Text:
At a turn of the ravine appeared a village with its
few houses, mostly with their blind walls to the path, and, at first, no
living soul in sight.
Label: joseph

Text:
Three tall platanes, very ragged as to their bark
and very poor as to foliage, stood in a group in an open space; and
Citizen Peyrol was cheered up by the sight of a dog sleeping in the
shade.
Label: joseph

Text:
The mule swerved with great determination towards a massive stone
trough under the village fountain.
Label: joseph

Text:
Peyrol, looking round from the saddle
while the mule drank, could see no signs of an inn.
Label: joseph

Text:
Then, examining the
ground nearer to him, he perceived a ragged man sitting on a stone.
Label: joseph

Text:
He
had a broad leathern belt and his legs were bare to the knee.
Label: joseph

Text:
He was
contemplating the stranger on the mule with stony surprise.
Label: joseph

Text:
His dark
nut-brown face contrasted strongly with his grey shock of hair.
Label: joseph

Text:
At a
sign from Peyrol he showed no reluctance and approached him readily
without changing the stony character of his stare.
Label: joseph

Text:
The thought that if he had remained at home he would have probably
looked like that man crossed unbidden the mind of Peyrol.
Label: joseph

Text:
With that
gravity from which he seldom departed he inquired if there were any
inhabitants besides himself in the village.
Label: joseph

Text:
Then, to Peyrol’s surprise,
that destitute idler smiled pleasantly and said that the people were out
looking after their bits of land.
Label: joseph

Text:
There was enough of the peasant-born in Peyrol, still, to remark that he
had seen no man, woman, or child, or four-footed beast for hours, and
that he would hardly have thought that there was any land worth looking
after anywhere around.
Label: joseph

Text: But the other insisted.
Label: joseph

Text:
Well, they were working
on it all the same, at least those that had any.
Label: joseph

Text:
At the sound of the voices the dog got up with a strange air of being
all backbone, and, approaching in dismal fidelity, stood with his nose
close to his master’s calves.
Label: joseph

Text:
“And you,” said Peyrol, “you have no land then?” The man took his time
to answer.
Label: joseph

Text:
“I have a boat.”

Peyrol became interested when the man explained that his boat was on the
salt pond, the large, deserted and opaque sheet of water lying dead
between the two great bays of the living sea.
Label: joseph

Text:
Peyrol wondered aloud why
anyone should want a boat on it.
Label: joseph

Text: “There is fish there,” said the man.
Label: joseph

Text: “And is the boat all your worldly goods?” asked Peyrol.
Label: joseph

Text:
The flies buzzed, the mule hung its head, moving its ears and flapping
its thin tail languidly.
Label: joseph

Text:
“I have a sort of hut down by the lagoon and a net or two,” the man
confessed, as it were.
Label: joseph

Text:
Peyrol, looking down, completed the list by
saying: “And this dog.”

The man again took his time to say:

“He is company.”

Peyrol sat as serious as a judge.
Label: joseph

Text:
“You haven’t much to make a living
of,” he delivered himself at last.
Label: joseph

Text: “However!...
Label: joseph

Text:
Is there no inn, café,
or some place where one could put up for a day?
Label: joseph

Text:
I have heard up inland
that there was some such place.”

“I will show it to you,” said the man, who then went back to where he
had been sitting and picked up a large empty basket before he led the
way.
Label: joseph

Text:
His dog followed with his head and tail low, and then came Peyrol
dangling his heels against the sides of the intelligent mule, which
seemed to know beforehand all that was going to happen.
Label: joseph

Text:
At the corner
where the houses ended there stood an old wooden cross stuck into a
square block of stone.
Label: joseph

Text:
The lonely boatman of the Lagoon of Pesquiers
pointed in the direction of a branching path where the rises terminating
the peninsula sank into a shallow pass.
Label: joseph

Text:
There were leaning pines on the
skyline, and in the pass itself dull silvery green patches of olive
orchards below a long yellow wall backed by dark cypresses, and the red
roofs of buildings which seemed to belong to a farm.
Label: joseph

Text: “Will they lodge me there?” asked Peyrol.
Label: joseph

Text: ﻿CHAPTER I.
Label: mark

Text:
You don’t know about me without you have read a book by the name of The
Adventures of Tom Sawyer; but that ain’t no matter.
Label: mark

Text:
That book was made
by Mr. Mark Twain, and he told the truth, mainly.
Label: mark

Text:
There was things
which he stretched, but mainly he told the truth.
Label: mark

Text: That is nothing.
Label: mark

Text:
I
never seen anybody but lied one time or another, without it was Aunt
Polly, or the widow, or maybe Mary.
Label: mark

Text:
Aunt Polly—Tom’s Aunt Polly, she
is—and Mary, and the Widow Douglas is all told about in that book,
which is mostly a true book, with some stretchers, as I said before.
Label: mark

Text:
Now the way that the book winds up is this: Tom and me found the money
that the robbers hid in the cave, and it made us rich.
Label: mark

Text:
We got six
thousand dollars apiece—all gold.
Label: mark

Text:
It was an awful sight of money when
it was piled up.
Label: mark

Text:
Well, Judge Thatcher he took it and put it out at
interest, and it fetched us a dollar a day apiece all the year
round—more than a body could tell what to do with.
Label: mark

Text:
The Widow Douglas
she took me for her son, and allowed she would sivilize me; but it was
rough living in the house all the time, considering how dismal regular
and decent the widow was in all her ways; and so when I couldn’t stand
it no longer I lit out.
Label: mark

Text:
I got into my old rags and my sugar-hogshead
again, and was free and satisfied.
Label: mark

Text:
But Tom Sawyer he hunted me up and
said he was going to start a band of robbers, and I might join if I
would go back to the widow and be respectable.
Label: mark

Text: So I went back.
Label: mark

Text:
The widow she cried over me, and called me a poor lost lamb, and she
called me a lot of other names, too, but she never meant no harm by it.
Label: mark

Text:
She put me in them new clothes again, and I couldn’t do nothing but
sweat and sweat, and feel all cramped up.
Label: mark

Text:
Well, then, the old thing
commenced again.
Label: mark

Text:
The widow rung a bell for supper, and you had to come
to time.
Label: mark

Text:
When you got to the table you couldn’t go right to eating, but
you had to wait for the widow to tuck down her head and grumble a
little over the victuals, though there warn’t really anything the
matter with them,—that is, nothing only everything was cooked by
itself.
Label: mark

Text:
In a barrel of odds and ends it is different; things get mixed
up, and the juice kind of swaps around, and the things go better.
Label: mark

Text:
After supper she got out her book and learned me about Moses and the
Bulrushers, and I was in a sweat to find out all about him; but
by-and-by she let it out that Moses had been dead a considerable long
time; so then I didn’t care no more about him, because I don’t take no
stock in dead people.
Label: mark

Text: Pretty soon I wanted to smoke, and asked the widow to let me.
Label: mark

Text:
But she
wouldn’t.
Label: mark

Text:
She said it was a mean practice and wasn’t clean, and I must
try to not do it any more.
Label: mark

Text: That is just the way with some people.
Label: mark

Text:
They
get down on a thing when they don’t know nothing about it.
Label: mark

Text:
Here she was
a-bothering about Moses, which was no kin to her, and no use to
anybody, being gone, you see, yet finding a power of fault with me for
doing a thing that had some good in it.
Label: mark

Text:
And she took snuff, too; of
course that was all right, because she done it herself.
Label: mark

Text:
Her sister, Miss Watson, a tolerable slim old maid, with goggles on,
had just come to live with her, and took a set at me now with a
spelling-book.
Label: mark

Text:
She worked me middling hard for about an hour, and then
the widow made her ease up.
Label: mark

Text: I couldn’t stood it much longer.
Label: mark

Text:
Then for
an hour it was deadly dull, and I was fidgety.
Label: mark

Text:
Miss Watson would say,
“Don’t put your feet up there, Huckleberry;” and “Don’t scrunch up like
that, Huckleberry—set up straight;” and pretty soon she would say,
“Don’t gap and stretch like that, Huckleberry—why don’t you try to
behave?” Then she told me all about the bad place, and I said I wished
I was there.
Label: mark

Text: She got mad then, but I didn’t mean no harm.
Label: mark

Text:
All I wanted
was to go somewheres; all I wanted was a change, I warn’t particular.
Label: mark

Text:
She said it was wicked to say what I said; said she wouldn’t say it for
the whole world; she was going to live so as to go to the good place.
Label: mark

Text:
Well, I couldn’t see no advantage in going where she was going, so I
made up my mind I wouldn’t try for it.
Label: mark

Text:
But I never said so, because it
would only make trouble, and wouldn’t do no good.
Label: mark

Text:
Now she had got a start, and she went on and told me all about the good
place.
Label: mark

Text:
She said all a body would have to do there was to go around all
day long with a harp and sing, forever and ever.
Label: mark

Text:
So I didn’t think much
of it.
Label: mark

Text: But I never said so.
Label: mark

Text:
I asked her if she reckoned Tom Sawyer
would go there, and she said not by a considerable sight.
Label: mark

Text:
I was glad
about that, because I wanted him and me to be together.
Label: mark

Text: Miss Watson she kept pecking at me, and it got tiresome and lonesome.
Label: mark

Text:
By-and-by they fetched the niggers in and had prayers, and then
everybody was off to bed.
Label: mark

Text:
I went up to my room with a piece of candle,
and put it on the table.
Label: mark

Text:
Then I set down in a chair by the window and
tried to think of something cheerful, but it warn’t no use.
Label: mark

Text:
I felt so
lonesome I most wished I was dead.
Label: mark

Text:
The stars were shining, and the
leaves rustled in the woods ever so mournful; and I heard an owl, away
off, who-whooing about somebody that was dead, and a whippowill and a
dog crying about somebody that was going to die; and the wind was
trying to whisper something to me, and I couldn’t make out what it was,
and so it made the cold shivers run over me.
Label: mark

Text:
Then away out in the woods
I heard that kind of a sound that a ghost makes when it wants to tell
about something that’s on its mind and can’t make itself understood,
and so can’t rest easy in its grave, and has to go about that way every
night grieving.
Label: mark

Text:
I got so down-hearted and scared I did wish I had some
company.
Label: mark

Text:
Pretty soon a spider went crawling up my shoulder, and I
flipped it off and it lit in the candle; and before I could budge it
was all shriveled up.
Label: mark

Text:
I didn’t need anybody to tell me that that was an
awful bad sign and would fetch me some bad luck, so I was scared and
most shook the clothes off of me.
Label: mark

Text:
I got up and turned around in my
tracks three times and crossed my breast every time; and then I tied up
a little lock of my hair with a thread to keep witches away.
Label: mark

Text:
But I
hadn’t no confidence.
Label: mark

Text:
You do that when you’ve lost a horseshoe that
you’ve found, instead of nailing it up over the door, but I hadn’t ever
heard anybody say it was any way to keep off bad luck when you’d killed
a spider.
Label: mark
mark

Text:
Well, after a long time I heard the clock away off in the town go
boom—boom—boom—twelve licks; and all still again—stiller than ever.
Label: mark

Text:
Pretty soon I heard a twig snap down in the dark amongst the
trees—something was a stirring.
Label: mark

Text: I set still and listened.
Label: mark

Text:
Directly I
could just barely hear a “_me-yow!
Label: mark

Text: me-yow!_” down there.
Label: mark

Text: That was good!
Label: mark

Text: Says I, “_me-yow!
Label: mark

Text:
me-yow!_” as soft as I could, and then I put out the
light and scrambled out of the window on to the shed.
Label: mark

Text:
Then I slipped
down to the ground and crawled in among the trees, and, sure enough,
there was Tom Sawyer waiting for me.
Label: mark

Text: CHAPTER II.
Label: mark

Text:
We went tiptoeing along a path amongst the trees back towards the end
of the widow’s garden, stooping down so as the branches wouldn’t scrape
our heads.
Label: mark

Text:
When we was passing by the kitchen I fell over a root and
made a noise.
Label: mark

Text: We scrouched down and laid still.
Label: mark

Text:
Miss Watson’s big
nigger, named Jim, was setting in the kitchen door; we could see him
pretty clear, because there was a light behind him.
Label: mark

Text:
He got up and
stretched his neck out about a minute, listening.
Label: mark

Text:
Then he says:

“Who dah?”

He listened some more; then he come tiptoeing down and stood right
between us; we could a touched him, nearly.
Label: mark

Text:
Well, likely it was minutes
and minutes that there warn’t a sound, and we all there so close
together.
Label: mark

Text:
There was a place on my ankle that got to itching, but I
dasn’t scratch it; and then my ear begun to itch; and next my back,
right between my shoulders.
Label: mark

Text: Seemed like I’d die if I couldn’t scratch.
Label: mark

Text: Well, I’ve noticed that thing plenty times since.
Label: mark

Text:
If you are with the
quality, or at a funeral, or trying to go to sleep when you ain’t
sleepy—if you are anywheres where it won’t do for you to scratch, why
you will itch all over in upwards of a thousand places.
Label: mark

Text:
Pretty soon Jim
says:

“Say, who is you?
Label: mark

Text: Whar is you?
Label: mark

Text: Dog my cats ef I didn’ hear sumf’n.
Label: mark

Text:
Well, I know what I’s gwyne to do: I’s gwyne to set down here and
listen tell I hears it agin.”

So he set down on the ground betwixt me and Tom.
Label: mark

Text:
He leaned his back up
against a tree, and stretched his legs out till one of them most
touched one of mine.
Label: mark

Text: My nose begun to itch.
Label: mark

Text:
It itched till the tears
come into my eyes.
Label: mark

Text: But I dasn’t scratch.
Label: mark

Text:
Then it begun to itch on the
inside.
Label: mark

Text: Next I got to itching underneath.
Label: mark

Text:
I didn’t know how I was going
to set still.
Label: mark

Text:
This miserableness went on as much as six or seven
minutes; but it seemed a sight longer than that.
Label: mark

Text:
I was itching in
eleven different places now.
Label: mark

Text:
I reckoned I couldn’t stand it more’n a
minute longer, but I set my teeth hard and got ready to try.
Label: mark

Text:
Just then
Jim begun to breathe heavy; next he begun to snore—and then I was
pretty soon comfortable again.
Label: mark

Text:
Tom he made a sign to me—kind of a little noise with his mouth—and we
went creeping away on our hands and knees.
Label: mark

Text:
When we was ten foot off Tom
whispered to me, and wanted to tie Jim to the tree for fun.
Label: mark

Text:
But I said
no; he might wake and make a disturbance, and then they’d find out I
warn’t in.
Label: mark

Text:
Then Tom said he hadn’t got candles enough, and he would
slip in the kitchen and get some more.
Label: mark

Text: I didn’t want him to try.
Label: mark

Text:
I said
Jim might wake up and come.
Label: mark

Text:
But Tom wanted to resk it; so we slid in
there and got three candles, and Tom laid five cents on the table for
pay.
Label: mark

Text:
Then we got out, and I was in a sweat to get away; but nothing
would do Tom but he must crawl to where Jim was, on his hands and
knees, and play something on him.
Label: mark

Text:
I waited, and it seemed a good while,
everything was so still and lonesome.
Label: mark

Text:
As soon as Tom was back we cut along the path, around the garden fence,
and by-and-by fetched up on the steep top of the hill the other side of
the house.
Label: mark

Text:
Tom said he slipped Jim’s hat off of his head and hung it on
a limb right over him, and Jim stirred a little, but he didn’t wake.
Label: mark

Text:
Afterwards Jim said the witches bewitched him and put him in a trance,
and rode him all over the State, and then set him under the trees
again, and hung his hat on a limb to show who done it.
Label: mark

Text:
And next time
Jim told it he said they rode him down to New Orleans; and, after that,
every time he told it he spread it more and more, till by-and-by he
said they rode him all over the world, and tired him most to death, and
his back was all over saddle-boils.
Label: mark

Text:
Jim was monstrous proud about it,
and he got so he wouldn’t hardly notice the other niggers.
Label: mark

Text:
Niggers
would come miles to hear Jim tell about it, and he was more looked up
to than any nigger in that country.
Label: mark

Text:
Strange niggers would stand with
their mouths open and look him all over, same as if he was a wonder.
Label: mark

Text:
Niggers is always talking about witches in the dark by the kitchen
fire; but whenever one was talking and letting on to know all about
such things, Jim would happen in and say, “Hm!
Label: mark

Text:
What you know ’bout
witches?” and that nigger was corked up and had to take a back seat.
Label: mark

Text:
Jim always kept that five-center piece round his neck with a string,
and said it was a charm the devil give to him with his own hands, and
told him he could cure anybody with it and fetch witches whenever he
wanted to just by saying something to it; but he never told what it was
he said to it.
Label: mark

Text:
Niggers would come from all around there and give Jim
anything they had, just for a sight of that five-center piece; but they
wouldn’t touch it, because the devil had had his hands on it.
Label: mark

Text:
Jim was
most ruined for a servant, because he got stuck up on account of having
seen the devil and been rode by witches.
Label: mark

Text:
Well, when Tom and me got to the edge of the hilltop we looked away
down into the village and could see three or four lights twinkling,
where there was sick folks, maybe; and the stars over us was sparkling
ever so fine; and down by the village was the river, a whole mile
broad, and awful still and grand.
Label: mark

Text:
We went down the hill and found Jo
Harper and Ben Rogers, and two or three more of the boys, hid in the
old tanyard.
Label: mark

Text:
So we unhitched a skiff and pulled down the river two mile
and a half, to the big scar on the hillside, and went ashore.
Label: mark

Text:
We went to a clump of bushes, and Tom made everybody swear to keep the
secret, and then showed them a hole in the hill, right in the thickest
part of the bushes.
Label: mark

Text:
Then we lit the candles, and crawled in on our
hands and knees.
Label: mark

Text:
We went about two hundred yards, and then the cave
opened up.
Label: mark

Text:
Tom poked about amongst the passages, and pretty soon ducked
under a wall where you wouldn’t a noticed that there was a hole.
Label: mark

Text:
We
went along a narrow place and got into a kind of room, all damp and
sweaty and cold, and there we stopped.
Label: mark

Text:
Tom says:

“Now, we’ll start this band of robbers and call it Tom Sawyer’s Gang.
Label: mark

Text:
Everybody that wants to join has got to take an oath, and write his
name in blood.”

Everybody was willing.
Label: mark

Text:
So Tom got out a sheet of paper that he had
wrote the oath on, and read it.
Label: mark

Text:
It swore every boy to stick to the
band, and never tell any of the secrets; and if anybody done anything
to any boy in the band, whichever boy was ordered to kill that person
and his family must do it, and he mustn’t eat and he mustn’t sleep till
he had killed them and hacked a cross in their breasts, which was the
sign of the band.
Label: mark

Text:
And nobody that didn’t belong to the band could use
that mark, and if he did he must be sued; and if he done it again he
must be killed.
Label: mark

Text:
And if anybody that belonged to the band told the
secrets, he must have his throat cut, and then have his carcass burnt
up and the ashes scattered all around, and his name blotted off of the
list with blood and never mentioned again by the gang, but have a curse
put on it and be forgot forever.
Label: mark

Text:
Everybody said it was a real beautiful oath, and asked Tom if he got it
out of his own head.
Label: mark

Text:
He said, some of it, but the rest was out of
pirate-books and robber-books, and every gang that was high-toned had
it.
Label: mark

Text:
Some thought it would be good to kill the _families_ of boys that told
the secrets.
Label: mark

Text:
Tom said it was a good idea, so he took a pencil and wrote
it in.
Label: mark

Text:
Then Ben Rogers says:

“Here’s Huck Finn, he hain’t got no family; what you going to do ’bout
him?”

“Well, hain’t he got a father?” says Tom Sawyer.
Label: mark

Text: “Yes, he’s got a father, but you can’t never find him these days.
Label: mark

Text:
He
used to lay drunk with the hogs in the tanyard, but he hain’t been seen
in these parts for a year or more.”

They talked it over, and they was going to rule me out, because they
said every boy must have a family or somebody to kill, or else it
wouldn’t be fair and square for the others.
Label: mark

Text:
Well, nobody could think of
anything to do—everybody was stumped, and set still.
Label: mark

Text:
I was most ready
to cry; but all at once I thought of a way, and so I offered them Miss
Watson—they could kill her.
Label: mark

Text:
Everybody said:

“Oh, she’ll do.
Label: mark

Text: That’s all right.
Label: mark

Text:
Huck can come in.”

Then they all stuck a pin in their fingers to get blood to sign with,
and I made my mark on the paper.
Label: mark

Text:
“Now,” says Ben Rogers, “what’s the line of business of this Gang?”

“Nothing only robbery and murder,” Tom said.
Label: mark

Text:
“But who are we going to rob?—houses, or cattle, or—”

“Stuff!
Label: mark

stealing cattle and such things ain’t robbery; it’s burglary,”
says Tom Sawyer.
Label: mark

Text: “We ain’t burglars.
Label: mark

Text: That ain’t no sort of style.
Label: mark

Text:
We
are highwaymen.
Label: mark

Text:

“Must we always kill the people?”

“Oh, certainly.

Label: mark

“Ransomed?
Label: mark

“I don’t know.

Label: mark

“But how can we do it if we don’t know what it is?”

“Why, blame it all, we’ve _got_ to do it.

Label: mark

Label: mark

Now, what do you _reckon_ it

“Well, I don’t know.

“Now, that’s something _like_.

Little Tommy Barnes was asleep now, and when they waked him up he was

So they all made fun of him, and called him cry-baby, and that made him

Text:

They agreed to get

Text:
I clumb up the shed and crept into my window just before day was
breaking.
Label: mark

Text:
My new clothes was all greased up and clayey, and I was
dog-tired.
Label: mark

Label: mark

him the knack of it, and he strode down the street with his mouth full
of harmony and his soul full of gratitude.
Label: mark

Text:
He felt much as an
astronomer feels who has discovered a new planet--no doubt, as far as
strong, deep, unalloyed pleasure is concerned, the advantage was with
the boy, not the astronomer.
Label: mark

Text: The summer evenings were long.
Label: mark

Text: It was not dark, yet.
Label: mark

Text:
Presently Tom
checked his whistle.
Label: mark

Text:
A stranger was before him--a boy a shade larger
than himself.
Label: mark

Text:
A new-comer of any age or either sex was an impressive
curiosity in the poor little shabby village of St. Petersburg.
Label: mark

Text:
This boy
was well dressed, too--well dressed on a week-day.
Label: mark

Text:
This was simply
astounding.
Label: mark

Text:
His cap was a dainty thing, his close-buttoned blue cloth
roundabout was new and natty, and so were his pantaloons.
Label: mark

Text:
He had shoes
on--and it was only Friday.
Label: mark

Text:
He even wore a necktie, a bright bit of
ribbon.
Label: mark

Text: He had a citified air about him that ate into Tom's vitals.
Label: mark

Text:
The
more Tom stared at the splendid marvel, the higher he turned up his
nose at his finery and the shabbier and shabbier his own outfit seemed
to him to grow.
Label: mark

Text: Neither boy spoke.
Label: mark

Text:
If one moved, the other moved--but
only sidewise, in a circle; they kept face to face and eye to eye all
the time.
Label: mark

Text:
Finally Tom said:

"I can lick you!"
Label: mark

Label: mark

Then Tom said:

Label: mark

Text:
The new boy took two broad coppers out of his pocket and held them out
with derision.
Label: mark

Text: Tom struck them to the ground.
Label: mark

Text:
In an instant both boys
were rolling and tumbling in the dirt, gripped together like cats; and
for the space of a minute they tugged and tore at each other's hair and
clothes, punched and scratched each other's nose, and covered
themselves with dust and glory.
Label: mark

Text:
Presently the confusion took form, and
through the fog of battle Tom appeared, seated astride the new boy, and
pounding him with his fists.

Text: "Holler 'nuff!"
Label: mark

Label: mark

Label: mark

Text: He was crying--mainly from rage.
Label: mark

Text: "Holler 'nuff!"
Label: mark

Label: mark

Label: mark

and Tom let him up

"Now that'll learn you.
Label: mark

Text:
Better look out who you're fooling with next

Label: mark

Text:
The new boy went off brushing the dust from his clothes, sobbing,

Label: mark

Text:
To which Tom responded with jeers, and started off in high feather, and

Label: mark

Text:
Tom chased the traitor home, and thus found out where he
lived.
Label: mark

Text:
He then held a position at the gate for some time, daring the
enemy to come outside, but the enemy only made faces at him through the
window and declined.
Label: mark

Text:
At last the enemy's mother appeared, and called
Tom a bad, vicious, vulgar child, and ordered him away.
Label: mark

Text:
So he went
away; but he said he "'lowed" to "lay" for that boy.
Label: mark

Text:
He got home pretty late that night, and when he climbed cautiously in
at the window, he uncovered an ambuscade, in the person of his aunt;
and when she saw the state his clothes were in her resolution to turn
his Saturday holiday into captivity at hard labor became adamantine in
its firmness.
Label: mark

Text:
﻿CHAPTER IV

THE sun rose upon a tranquil world, and beamed down upon the peaceful
village like a benediction.
Label: mark

Text:
Breakfast over, Aunt Polly had family
worship: it began with a prayer built from the ground up of solid
courses of Scriptural quotations, welded together with a thin mortar of
originality; and from the summit of this she delivered a grim chapter
of the Mosaic Law, as from Sinai.
Label: mark

Text:
Then Tom girded up his loins, so to speak, and went to work to "get
his verses."
Label: mark

Text: Sid had learned his lesson days before.
Label: mark

Text:
Tom bent all his
energies to the memorizing of five verses, and he chose part of the
Sermon on the Mount, because he could find no verses that were shorter.
Label: mark

Text:
At the end of half an hour Tom had a vague general idea of his lesson,
but no more, for his mind was traversing the whole field of human
thought, and his hands were busy with distracting recreations.
Label: mark

Text:
Mary
took his book to hear him recite, and he tried to find his way through
the fog:

"Blessed are the--a--a--"

"Poor"--

"Yes--poor; blessed are the poor--a--a--"

"In spirit--"

"In spirit; blessed are the poor in spirit, for they--they--"

"THEIRS--"

"For THEIRS.
Label: mark

Text:
Blessed are the poor in spirit, for theirs is the kingdom
of heaven.
Label: mark

Text:
Blessed are they that mourn, for they--they--"

"Sh--"

"For they--a--"

"S, H, A--"

"For they S, H--Oh, I don't know what it is!"
Label: mark

Text: "SHALL!"
Label: mark

Text: "Oh, SHALL!
Label: mark

Text:
for they shall--for they shall--a--a--shall mourn--a--a--
blessed are they that shall--they that--a--they that shall mourn, for
they shall--a--shall WHAT?
Label: mark

Text:
Why don't you tell me, Mary?--what do you
want to be so mean for?"
Label: mark

Text: "Oh, Tom, you poor thick-headed thing, I'm not teasing you.
Label: mark

Text:
I wouldn't
do that.
Label: mark

Text: You must go and learn it again.
Label: mark

Text:
Don't you be discouraged, Tom,
you'll manage it--and if you do, I'll give you something ever so nice.
Label: mark

Text: There, now, that's a good boy."
Label: mark

Text: "All right!
Label: mark

Label: mark

Label: mark

Label: mark

Label: mark

Text: All right, I'll tackle it again."
Label: mark

Text:
And he did "tackle it again"--and under the double pressure of
curiosity and prospective gain he did it with such spirit that he
accomplished a shining success.
Label: mark

Text:
Mary gave him a brand-new "Barlow"
knife worth twelve and a half cents; and the convulsion of delight that
swept his system shook him to his foundations.
Label: mark

Text:
True, the knife would
not cut anything, but it was a "sure-enough" Barlow, and there was
inconceivable grandeur in that--though where the Western boys ever got
the idea that such a weapon could possibly be counterfeited to its
injury is an imposing mystery and will always remain so, perhaps.
Label: mark

Text:
Tom
contrived to scarify the cupboard with it, and was arranging to begin
on the bureau, when he was called off to dress for Sunday-school.
Label: mark

Text:
Mary gave him a tin basin of water and a piece of soap, and he went
outside the door and set the basin on a little bench there; then he
dipped the soap in the water and laid it down; turned up his sleeves;
poured out the water on the ground, gently, and then entered the
kitchen and began to wipe his face diligently on the towel behind the
door.
Label: mark

Text:
But Mary removed the towel and said:

"Now ain't you ashamed, Tom.
Label: mark

Text: You mustn't be so bad.
Label: mark

Text:
Water won't hurt
you."
Label: mark

Text: Tom was a trifle disconcerted.
Label: mark

Text:
The basin was refilled, and this time
he stood over it a little while, gathering resolution; took in a big
breath and began.
Label: mark

Text:
When he entered the kitchen presently, with both eyes
shut and groping for the towel with his hands, an honorable testimony
of suds and water was dripping from his face.
Label: mark

Text:
But when he emerged from
the towel, he was not yet satisfactory, for the clean territory stopped
short at his chin and his jaws, like a mask; below and beyond this line
there was a dark expanse of unirrigated soil that spread downward in
front and backward around his neck.
Label: mark

Text:
Mary took him in hand, and when she
was done with him he was a man and a brother, without distinction of
color, and his saturated hair was neatly brushed, and its short curls
wrought into a dainty and symmetrical general effect.
Label: mark

Text:
[He privately
smoothed out the curls, with labor and difficulty, and plastered his
hair close down to his head; for he held curls to be effeminate, and
his own filled his life with bitterness.]
Label: mark

Text:
Then Mary got out a suit of
his clothing that had been used only on Sundays during two years--they
were simply called his "other clothes"--and so by that we know the
size of his wardrobe.
Label: mark

Text:
The girl "put him to rights" after he had dressed
himself; she buttoned his neat roundabout up to his chin, turned his
vast shirt collar down over his shoulders, brushed him off and crowned
him with his speckled straw hat.
Label: mark

Text:
He now looked exceedingly improved and
uncomfortable.
Label: mark

Text:
He was fully as uncomfortable as he looked; for there
was a restraint about whole clothes and cleanliness that galled him.
Label: mark

Text:
He
hoped that Mary would forget his shoes, but the hope was blighted; she
coated them thoroughly with tallow, as was the custom, and brought them
out.
Label: mark

Text:
He lost his temper and said he was always being made to do
everything he didn't want to do.
Label: mark

Text:
But Mary said, persuasively:

"Please, Tom--that's a good boy."
Label: mark

Text: So he got into the shoes snarling.
Label: mark

Text:
Mary was soon ready, and the three
children set out for Sunday-school--a place that Tom hated with his
whole heart; but Sid and Mary were fond of it.
Label: mark

Text:
Sabbath-school hours were from nine to half-past ten; and then church
service.
Label: mark

Text:
Two of the children always remained for the sermon
voluntarily, and the other always remained too--for stronger reasons.
Label: mark

Text:
The church's high-backed, uncushioned pews would seat about three
hundred persons; the edifice was but a small, plain affair, with a sort
of pine board tree-box on top of it for a steeple.
Label: mark

Text:
At the door Tom
dropped back a step and accosted a Sunday-dressed comrade:

"Say, Billy, got a yaller ticket?"
Label: mark

Text: "Yes."
Label: mark

Text: "What'll you take for her?"
Label: mark

Text: "What'll you give?"
Label: mark

Text: "Piece of lickrish and a fish-hook."
Label: mark

Text: "Less see 'em."
Label: mark

Text: Tom exhibited.
Label: mark

Text: They were satisfactory, and the property changed hands.
Label: mark

Text:
Then Tom traded a couple of white alleys for three red tickets, and
some small trifle or other for a couple of blue ones.
Label: mark

Text:
He waylaid other
boys as they came, and went on buying tickets of various colors ten or
fifteen minutes longer.
Label: mark

Text:
He entered the church, now, with a swarm of
clean and noisy boys and girls, proceeded to his seat and started a
quarrel with the first boy that came handy.
Label: mark

Text:
The teacher, a grave,
elderly man, interfered; then turned his back a moment and Tom pulled a
boy's hair in the next bench, and was absorbed in his book when the boy
turned around; stuck a pin in another boy, presently, in order to hear
him say "Ouch!"
Label: mark

Text: and got a new reprimand from his teacher.
Label: mark

Text:
Tom's whole
class were of a pattern--restless, noisy, and troublesome.
Label: mark

Text:
When they
came to recite their lessons, not one of them knew his verses
perfectly, but had to be prompted all along.
Label: mark

Text:
However, they worried
through, and each got his reward--in small blue tickets, each with a
passage of Scripture on it; each blue ticket was pay for two verses of
the recitation.
Label: mark

Text:
Ten blue tickets equalled a red one, and could be
exchanged for it; ten red tickets equalled a yellow one; for ten yellow
tickets the superintendent gave a very plainly bound Bible (worth forty
cents in those easy times) to the pupil.
Label: mark

Text:
How many of my readers would
have the industry and application to memorize two thousand verses, even
for a Dore Bible?
Label: mark

Text:
And yet Mary had acquired two Bibles in this way--it
was the patient work of two years--and a boy of German parentage had
won four or five.
Label: mark

Text:
He once recited three thousand verses without
stopping; but the strain upon his mental faculties was too great, and
he was little better than an idiot from that day forth--a grievous
misfortune for the school, for on great occasions, before company, the
superintendent (as Tom expressed it) had always made this boy come out
and "spread himself."
Label: mark

Text:
Only the older pupils managed to keep their
tickets and stick to their tedious work long enough to get a Bible, and
so the delivery of one of these prizes was a rare and noteworthy
circumstance; the successful pupil was so great and conspicuous for
that day that on the spot every scholar's heart was fired with a fresh
ambition that often lasted a couple of weeks.
Label: mark

Text:
It is possible that Tom's
mental stomach had never really hungered for one of those prizes, but
unquestionably his entire being had for many a day longed for the glory
and the eclat that came with it.
Label: mark

Text:
In due course the superintendent stood up in front of the pulpit, with
a closed hymn-book in his hand and his forefinger inserted between its
leaves, and commanded attention.
Label: mark

Text:
When a Sunday-school superintendent
makes his customary little speech, a hymn-book in the hand is as
necessary as is the inevitable sheet of music in the hand of a singer
who stands forward on the platform and sings a solo at a concert
--though why, is a mystery: for neither the hymn-book nor the sheet of
music is ever referred to by the sufferer.
Label: mark

Text:
This superintendent was a
slim creature of thirty-five, with a sandy goatee and short sandy hair;
he wore a stiff standing-collar whose upper edge almost reached his
ears and whose sharp points curved forward abreast the corners of his
mouth--a fence that compelled a straight lookout ahead, and a turning
of the whole body when a side view was required; his chin was propped
on a spreading cravat which was as broad and as long as a bank-note,
and had fringed ends; his boot toes were turned sharply up, in the
fashion of the day, like sleigh-runners--an effect patiently and
laboriously produced by the young men by sitting with their toes
pressed against a wall for hours together.
Label: mark

Text:
Mr. Walters was very earnest
of mien, and very sincere and honest at heart; and he held sacred
things and places in such reverence, and so separated them from worldly
matters, that unconsciously to himself his Sunday-school voice had
acquired a peculiar intonation which was wholly absent on week-days.
Label: mark

Text:
He
began after this fashion:

"Now, children, I want you all to sit up just as straight and pretty
as you can and give me all your attention for a minute or two.
Label: mark

Text:
There
--that is it.
Label: mark

Text: That is the way good little boys and girls should do.
Label: mark

Text:
I see
one little girl who is looking out of the window--I am afraid she
thinks I am out there somewhere--perhaps up in one of the trees making
a speech to the little birds.
Label: mark

Text: [Applausive titter.]
Label: mark

Text:
I want to tell you
how good it makes me feel to see so many bright, clean little faces
assembled in a place like this, learning to do right and be good."
Label: mark

Text:
And
so forth and so on.
Label: mark

Text:
It is not necessary to set down the rest of the
oration.
Label: mark

Text:
It was of a pattern which does not vary, and so it is familiar
to us all.
Label: mark

Text:
The latter third of the speech was marred by the resumption of fights
and other recreations among certain of the bad boys, and by fidgetings
and whisperings that extended far and wide, washing even to the bases
of isolated and incorruptible rocks like Sid and Mary.
Label: mark

Text:
But now every
sound ceased suddenly, with the subsidence of Mr. Walters' voice, and
the conclusion of the speech was received with a burst of silent
gratitude.
Label: mark

Text:
A good part of the whispering had been occasioned by an event which
was more or less rare--the entrance of visitors: lawyer Thatcher,
accompanied by a very feeble and aged man; a fine, portly, middle-aged
gentleman with iron-gray hair; and a dignified lady who was doubtless
the latter's wife.
Label: mark

Text: The lady was leading a child.
Label: mark

Text:
Tom had been restless
and full of chafings and repinings; conscience-smitten, too--he could
not meet Amy Lawrence's eye, he could not brook her loving gaze.
Label: mark

Text:
But
when he saw this small new-comer his soul was all ablaze with bliss in
a moment.
Label: mark

Text:
The next moment he was "showing off" with all his might
--cuffing boys, pulling hair, making faces--in a word, using every art
that seemed likely to fascinate a girl and win her applause.
Label: mark

Text:
His
exaltation had but one alloy--the memory of his humiliation in this
angel's garden--and that record in sand was fast washing out, under
the waves of happiness that were sweeping over it now.
Label: mark

Text:
The visitors were given the highest seat of honor, and as soon as Mr.
Walters' speech was finished, he introduced them to the school.
Label: mark

Text:
The
middle-aged man turned out to be a prodigious personage--no less a one
than the county judge--altogether the most august creation these
children had ever looked upon--and they wondered what kind of material
he was made of--and they half wanted to hear him roar, and were half
afraid he might, too.
Label: mark

Text:
He was from Constantinople, twelve miles away--so
he had travelled, and seen the world--these very eyes had looked upon
the county court-house--which was said to have a tin roof.
Label: mark

Text:
The awe
which these reflections inspired was attested by the impressive silence
and the ranks of staring eyes.
Label: mark

Text:
This was the great Judge Thatcher,
brother of their own lawyer.
Label: mark

Text:
Jeff Thatcher immediately went forward, to
be familiar with the great man and be envied by the school.
Label: mark

Text:
It would
have been music to his soul to hear the whisperings:

"Look at him, Jim!
Label: mark

Text: He's a going up there.
Label: mark

Text: Say--look!
Label: mark

Text:
he's a going to
shake hands with him--he IS shaking hands with him!
Label: mark

Text:
By jings, don't you
wish you was Jeff?"
Label: mark

Text:
Mr. Walters fell to "showing off," with all sorts of official
bustlings and activities, giving orders, delivering judgments,
discharging directions here, there, everywhere that he could find a

Label: mark

Text:
The librarian "showed off"--running hither and thither with his
arms full of books and making a deal of the splutter and fuss that

Label: mark

Text:
The young lady teachers "showed off"
--bending sweetly over pupils that were lately being boxed, lifting

Label: mark

Text:
The young gentlemen teachers "showed off" with small
scoldings and other little displays of authority and fine attention to

Label: mark

Text:
The little girls "showed off" in various ways, and the little boys

Label: mark

Text:
And above it all the great man sat and
beamed a majestic judicial smile upon all the house, and warmed himself
in the sun of his own grandeur--for he was "showing off," too.
Label: mark

Text:
There was only one thing wanting to make Mr. Walters' ecstasy
complete, and that was a chance to deliver a Bible-prize and exhibit a
prodigy.
Label: mark

Text:
Several pupils had a few yellow tickets, but none had enough
--he had been around among the star pupils inquiring.
Label: mark

Text:
He would have given
worlds, now, to have that German lad back again with a sound mind.
Label: mark

Text:
And now at this moment, when hope was dead, Tom Sawyer came forward
with nine yellow tickets, nine red tickets, and ten blue ones, and
demanded a Bible.
Label: mark

Text: This was a thunderbolt out of a clear sky.
Label: mark

Text:
Walters
was not expecting an application from this source for the next ten
years.
Label: mark

Text:
But there was no getting around it--here were the certified
checks, and they were good for their face.
Label: mark

Text:
Tom was therefore elevated
to a place with the Judge and the other elect, and the great news was
announced from headquarters.
Label: mark

Text:
It was the most stunning surprise of the
decade, and so profound was the sensation that it lifted the new hero
up to the judicial one's altitude, and the school had two marvels to
gaze upon in place of one.
Label: mark

Text:
The boys were all eaten up with envy--but
those that suffered the bitterest pangs were those who perceived too
late that they themselves had contributed to this hated splendor by
trading tickets to Tom for the wealth he had amassed in selling
whitewashing privileges.
Label: mark

Text:
These despised themselves, as being the dupes
of a wily fraud, a guileful snake in the grass.
Label: mark

Text:
The prize was delivered to Tom with as much effusion as the
superintendent could pump up under the circumstances; but it lacked
somewhat of the true gush, for the poor fellow's instinct taught him
that there was a mystery here that could not well bear the light,
perhaps; it was simply preposterous that this boy had warehoused two
thousand sheaves of Scriptural wisdom on his premises--a dozen would
strain his capacity, without a doubt.
Label: mark

Text:
Amy Lawrence was proud and glad, and she tried to make Tom see it in
her face--but he wouldn't look.

Text:
CHAPTER V

ABOUT half-past ten the cracked bell of the small church began to
ring, and presently the people began to gather for the morning sermon.
Label: mark

Text:
The Sunday-school children distributed themselves about the house and
occupied pews with their parents, so as to be under supervision.
Label: mark

Text:
Aunt
Polly came, and Tom and Sid and Mary sat with her--Tom being placed
next the aisle, in order that he might be as far away from the open
window and the seductive outside summer scenes as possible.
Label: mark

Text:
The crowd
filed up the aisles: the aged and needy postmaster, who had seen better
days; the mayor and his wife--for they had a mayor there, among other
unnecessaries; the justice of the peace; the widow Douglass, fair,
smart, and forty, a generous, good-hearted soul and well-to-do, her
hill mansion the only palace in the town, and the most hospitable and
much the most lavish in the matter of festivities that St. Petersburg
could boast; the bent and venerable Major and Mrs. Ward; lawyer
Riverson, the new notable from a distance; next the belle of the
village, followed by a troop of lawn-clad and ribbon-decked young
heart-breakers; then all the young clerks in town in a body--for they
had stood in the vestibule sucking their cane-heads, a circling wall of
oiled and simpering admirers, till the last girl had run their gantlet;
and last of all came the Model Boy, Willie Mufferson, taking as heedful
care of his mother as if she were cut glass.
Label: mark

Text:
He always brought his
mother to church, and was the pride of all the matrons.
Label: mark

Text:
The boys all
hated him, he was so good.
Label: mark

Text:
And besides, he had been "thrown up to them"
so much.
Label: mark

Text:
His white handkerchief was hanging out of his pocket behind, as
usual on Sundays--accidentally.
Label: mark

Text:
Tom had no handkerchief, and he looked
upon boys who had as snobs.
Label: mark

Text:
The congregation being fully assembled, now, the bell rang once more,
to warn laggards and stragglers, and then a solemn hush fell upon the
church which was only broken by the tittering and whispering of the
choir in the gallery.
Label: mark

Text:
The choir always tittered and whispered all
through service.
Label: mark

Text:
There was once a church choir that was not ill-bred,
but I have forgotten where it was, now.
Label: mark

Text:
It was a great many years ago,
and I can scarcely remember anything about it, but I think it was in
some foreign country.

The minister gave out the hymn, and read it through with a relish, in
a peculiar style which was much admired in that part of the country.
Label: mark

Text:
His voice began on a medium key and climbed steadily up till it reached
a certain point, where it bore with strong emphasis upon the topmost

  Shall I be car-ri-ed toe the skies, on flow'ry BEDS of ease,

  Whilst others fight to win the prize, and sail thro' BLOODY seas?

A good, generous prayer it was, and went

church; for the other churches of the village; for the village itself;
for the county; for the State; for the State officers; for the United
States; for the churches of the United States; for Congress; for the
President; for the officers of the Government; for poor sailors, tossed

grateful harvest of good.

Label: mark

﻿CHAPTER VIII

TOM dodged hither and thither through lanes until he was well out of
the track of returning scholars, and then fell into a moody jog.
