Text:
All the old graves were sunken in, there was not a
tombstone on the place; round-topped, worm-eaten boards staggered over
the graves, leaning for support and finding none.
Label: mark

Text:
"Sacred to the memory
of" So-and-So had been painted on them once, but it could no longer
have been read, on the most of them, now, even if there had been light.
Label: mark

Text:
A faint wind moaned through the trees, and Tom feared it might be the
spirits of the dead, complaining at being disturbed.
Label: mark

Text:
The boys talked
little, and only under their breath, for the time and the place and the
pervading solemnity and silence oppressed their spirits.
Label: mark

Text:
They found the
sharp new heap they were seeking, and ensconced themselves within the
protection of three great elms that grew in a bunch within a few feet
of the grave.
Label: mark

Text: Then they waited in silence for what seemed a long time.
Label: mark

Text:
The hooting
of a distant owl was all the sound that troubled the dead stillness.
Label: mark

Text: Tom's reflections grew oppressive.
Label: mark

Text: He must force some talk.
Label: mark

Text:
So he said
in a whisper:

"Hucky, do you believe the dead people like it for us to be here?"
Label: mark

Text:
Huckleberry whispered:

"I wisht I knowed.
Label: mark

Text: It's awful solemn like, AIN'T it?"
Label: mark

Text: "I bet it is."
Label: mark

Text:
There was a considerable pause, while the boys canvassed this matter
inwardly.
Label: mark

Text:
Then Tom whispered:

"Say, Hucky--do you reckon Hoss Williams hears us talking?"
Label: mark

Text: "O' course he does.
Label: mark

Text: Least his sperrit does."
Label: mark

Text:
Tom, after a pause:

"I wish I'd said Mister Williams.
Label: mark

Text: But I never meant any harm.
Label: mark

Text: Everybody calls him Hoss."
Label: mark

Text:
"A body can't be too partic'lar how they talk 'bout these-yer dead
people, Tom."
Label: mark

Text: This was a damper, and conversation died again.
Label: mark

Text:
Presently Tom seized his comrade's arm and said:

"Sh!"
Label: mark

Text: "What is it, Tom?"
Label: mark

Text: And the two clung together with beating hearts.
Label: mark

Text: "Sh!
Label: mark

Text: There 'tis again!
Label: mark

Text: Didn't you hear it?"
Label: mark

Text:
"I--"

"There!
Label: mark

Text: Now you hear it."
Label: mark

Text: "Lord, Tom, they're coming!
Label: mark

Text: They're coming, sure.
Label: mark

Text: What'll we do?"
Label: mark

Text: "I dono.
Label: mark

Text: Think they'll see us?"
Label: mark

Text: "Oh, Tom, they can see in the dark, same as cats.
Label: mark

Text:
I wisht I hadn't
come."
Label: mark

Text: "Oh, don't be afeard.
Label: mark

Text: I don't believe they'll bother us.
Label: mark

Text:
We ain't
doing any harm.
Label: mark

Text:
If we keep perfectly still, maybe they won't notice us
at all."
Label: mark

Text: "I'll try to, Tom, but, Lord, I'm all of a shiver."
Label: mark

Text: "Listen!"
Label: mark

Text: The boys bent their heads together and scarcely breathed.
Label: mark

Text:
A muffled
sound of voices floated up from the far end of the graveyard.
Label: mark

Text: "Look!
Label: mark

Text: See there!"
Label: mark

Text: whispered Tom.
Label: mark

Text: "What is it?"
Label: mark

Text: "It's devil-fire.
Label: mark

Text: Oh, Tom, this is awful."
Label: mark

Text:
Some vague figures approached through the gloom, swinging an
old-fashioned tin lantern that freckled the ground with innumerable
little spangles of light.
Label: mark

Text:
Presently Huckleberry whispered with a
shudder:

"It's the devils sure enough.
Label: mark

Text: Three of 'em!
Label: mark

Text: Lordy, Tom, we're goners!
Label: mark

Text: Can you pray?"
Label: mark

Text: "I'll try, but don't you be afeard.
Label: mark

Text: They ain't going to hurt us.
Label: mark

Text:
'Now
I lay me down to sleep, I--'"

"Sh!"
Label: mark

Text:
﻿CHAPTER XIII

TOM'S mind was made up now.
Label: mark

Text: He was gloomy and desperate.
Label: mark

Text:
He was a
forsaken, friendless boy, he said; nobody loved him; when they found
out what they had driven him to, perhaps they would be sorry; he had
tried to do right and get along, but they would not let him; since
nothing would do them but to be rid of him, let it be so; and let them
blame HIM for the consequences--why shouldn't they?
Label: mark

Text:
What right had the
friendless to complain?
Label: mark

Text:
Yes, they had forced him to it at last: he
would lead a life of crime.
Label: mark

Text: There was no choice.
Label: mark

Text:
By this time he was far down Meadow Lane, and the bell for school to
"take up" tinkled faintly upon his ear.
Label: mark

Text:
He sobbed, now, to think he
should never, never hear that old familiar sound any more--it was very
hard, but it was forced on him; since he was driven out into the cold
world, he must submit--but he forgave them.
Label: mark

Text:
Then the sobs came thick
and fast.
Label: mark

Text:
Just at this point he met his soul's sworn comrade, Joe Harper
--hard-eyed, and with evidently a great and dismal purpose in his heart.
Label: mark

Text: Plainly here were "two souls with but a single thought."
Label: mark

Text:
Tom, wiping
his eyes with his sleeve, began to blubber out something about a
resolution to escape from hard usage and lack of sympathy at home by
roaming abroad into the great world never to return; and ended by
hoping that Joe would not forget him.
Label: mark

Text:
But it transpired that this was a request which Joe had just been
going to make of Tom, and had come to hunt him up for that purpose.
Label: mark

Text:
His
mother had whipped him for drinking some cream which he had never
tasted and knew nothing about; it was plain that she was tired of him
and wished him to go; if she felt that way, there was nothing for him
to do but succumb; he hoped she would be happy, and never regret having
driven her poor boy out into the unfeeling world to suffer and die.
Label: mark

Text:
As the two boys walked sorrowing along, they made a new compact to
stand by each other and be brothers and never separate till death
relieved them of their troubles.
Label: mark

Text: Then they began to lay their plans.
Label: mark

Text:
Joe was for being a hermit, and living on crusts in a remote cave, and
dying, some time, of cold and want and grief; but after listening to
Tom, he conceded that there were some conspicuous advantages about a
life of crime, and so he consented to be a pirate.
Label: mark

Text:
Three miles below St. Petersburg, at a point where the Mississippi
River was a trifle over a mile wide, there was a long, narrow, wooded
island, with a shallow bar at the head of it, and this offered well as
a rendezvous.
Label: mark

Text:
It was not inhabited; it lay far over toward the further
shore, abreast a dense and almost wholly unpeopled forest.
Label: mark

Text:
So Jackson's
Island was chosen.
Label: mark

Text:
Who were to be the subjects of their piracies was a
matter that did not occur to them.
Label: mark

Text:
Then they hunted up Huckleberry
Finn, and he joined them promptly, for all careers were one to him; he
was indifferent.
Label: mark

Text:
They presently separated to meet at a lonely spot on
the river-bank two miles above the village at the favorite hour--which
was midnight.
Label: mark

Text:
There was a small log raft there which they meant to
capture.
Label: mark

Text:
Each would bring hooks and lines, and such provision as he
could steal in the most dark and mysterious way--as became outlaws.
Label: mark

Text:
And
before the afternoon was done, they had all managed to enjoy the sweet
glory of spreading the fact that pretty soon the town would "hear
something."
Label: mark

Text:
All who got this vague hint were cautioned to "be mum and
wait."
Label: mark

Text:
About midnight Tom arrived with a boiled ham and a few trifles,
and stopped in a dense undergrowth on a small bluff overlooking the
meeting-place.
Label: mark

Text: It was starlight, and very still.
Label: mark

Text:
The mighty river lay
like an ocean at rest.
Label: mark

Text:
Tom listened a moment, but no sound disturbed the
quiet.
Label: mark

Text: Then he gave a low, distinct whistle.
Label: mark

Text:
It was answered from under
the bluff.
Label: mark

Text:
Tom whistled twice more; these signals were answered in the
same way.
Label: mark

Text:
Then a guarded voice said:

"Who goes there?"
Label: mark

Text: "Tom Sawyer, the Black Avenger of the Spanish Main.
Label: mark

Text: Name your names."
Label: mark

Text: "Huck Finn the Red-Handed, and Joe Harper the Terror of the Seas."
Label: mark

Text:
Tom
had furnished these titles, from his favorite literature.
Label: mark

Text: "'Tis well.
Label: mark

Text: Give the countersign."
Label: mark

Text:
Two hoarse whispers delivered the same awful word simultaneously to
the brooding night:

"BLOOD!"
Label: mark

Text:
Then Tom tumbled his ham over the bluff and let himself down after it,
tearing both skin and clothes to some extent in the effort.
Label: mark

Text:
There was
an easy, comfortable path along the shore under the bluff, but it
lacked the advantages of difficulty and danger so valued by a pirate.
Label: mark

Text:
The Terror of the Seas had brought a side of bacon, and had about worn
himself out with getting it there.
Label: mark

Text:
Finn the Red-Handed had stolen a
skillet and a quantity of half-cured leaf tobacco, and had also brought
a few corn-cobs to make pipes with.
Label: mark

Text:
But none of the pirates smoked or
"chewed" but himself.
Label: mark

Text:
The Black Avenger of the Spanish Main said it
would never do to start without some fire.
Label: mark

Text:
That was a wise thought;
matches were hardly known there in that day.
Label: mark

Text:
They saw a fire
smouldering upon a great raft a hundred yards above, and they went
stealthily thither and helped themselves to a chunk.
Label: mark

Text:
They made an
imposing adventure of it, saying, "Hist!"
Label: mark

Text:
every now and then, and
suddenly halting with finger on lip; moving with hands on imaginary
dagger-hilts; and giving orders in dismal whispers that if "the foe"
stirred, to "let him have it to the hilt," because "dead men tell no
tales."
Label: mark

Text:
They knew well enough that the raftsmen were all down at the
village laying in stores or having a spree, but still that was no
excuse for their conducting this thing in an unpiratical way.
Label: mark

Text:
They shoved off, presently, Tom in command, Huck at the after oar and
Joe at the forward.
Label: mark

Text:
Tom stood amidships, gloomy-browed, and with folded
arms, and gave his orders in a low, stern whisper:

"Luff, and bring her to the wind!"
Label: mark

Text: "Aye-aye, sir!"
Label: mark

Text: "Steady, steady-y-y-y!"
Label: mark

Text: "Steady it is, sir!"
Label: mark

Text: "Let her go off a point!"
Label: mark

Text: "Point it is, sir!"
Label: mark

Text:
As the boys steadily and monotonously drove the raft toward mid-stream
it was no doubt understood that these orders were given only for
"style," and were not intended to mean anything in particular.
Label: mark

Text: "What sail's she carrying?"
Label: mark

Text: "Courses, tops'ls, and flying-jib, sir."
Label: mark

Text: "Send the r'yals up!
Label: mark

Text:
Lay out aloft, there, half a dozen of ye
--foretopmaststuns'l!
Label: mark

Text: Lively, now!"
Label: mark

Text: "Aye-aye, sir!"
Label: mark

Text: "Shake out that maintogalans'l!
Label: mark

Text: Sheets and braces!
Label: mark

Text: NOW my hearties!"
Label: mark

Text: "Aye-aye, sir!"
Label: mark

Text: "Hellum-a-lee--hard a port!
Label: mark

Text: Stand by to meet her when she comes!
Label: mark

Text:
Port,
port!
Label: mark

Text: NOW, men!
Label: mark

Text: With a will!
Label: mark

Text: Stead-y-y-y!"
Label: mark

Text: "Steady it is, sir!"
Label: mark

Text:
The raft drew beyond the middle of the river; the boys pointed her
head right, and then lay on their oars.
Label: mark

Text:
The river was not high, so
there was not more than a two or three mile current.
Label: mark

Text:
Hardly a word was
said during the next three-quarters of an hour.
Label: mark

Text:
Now the raft was
passing before the distant town.
Label: mark

Text:
Two or three glimmering lights showed
where it lay, peacefully sleeping, beyond the vague vast sweep of
star-gemmed water, unconscious of the tremendous event that was happening.
Label: mark

Text:
The Black Avenger stood still with folded arms, "looking his last" upon
the scene of his former joys and his later sufferings, and wishing
"she" could see him now, abroad on the wild sea, facing peril and death
with dauntless heart, going to his doom with a grim smile on his lips.
Label: mark

Text:
It was but a small strain on his imagination to remove Jackson's Island
beyond eyeshot of the village, and so he "looked his last" with a
broken and satisfied heart.
Label: mark

Text:
The other pirates were looking their last,
too; and they all looked so long that they came near letting the
current drift them out of the range of the island.
Label: mark

Text:
But they discovered
the danger in time, and made shift to avert it.
Label: mark

Text:
About two o'clock in
the morning the raft grounded on the bar two hundred yards above the
head of the island, and they waded back and forth until they had landed
their freight.
Label: mark

Text:
Part of the little raft's belongings consisted of an old
sail, and this they spread over a nook in the bushes for a tent to
shelter their provisions; but they themselves would sleep in the open
air in good weather, as became outlaws.
Label: mark

Text:
They built a fire against the side of a great log twenty or thirty
steps within the sombre depths of the forest, and then cooked some
bacon in the frying-pan for supper, and used up half of the corn "pone"
stock they had brought.
Label: mark

Text:
It seemed glorious sport to be feasting in that
wild, free way in the virgin forest of an unexplored and uninhabited
island, far from the haunts of men, and they said they never would
return to civilization.
Label: mark

Text:
The climbing fire lit up their faces and threw
its ruddy glare upon the pillared tree-trunks of their forest temple,
and upon the varnished foliage and festooning vines.
Label: mark

Text:
When the last crisp slice of bacon was gone, and the last allowance of
corn pone devoured, the boys stretched themselves out on the grass,
filled with contentment.
Label: mark

Text:
They could have found a cooler place, but they
would not deny themselves such a romantic feature as the roasting
camp-fire.
Label: mark

Text: "AIN'T it gay?"
Label: mark

Text: said Joe.
Label: mark

Text: "It's NUTS!"
Label: mark

Text: said Tom.
Label: mark

Text: "What would the boys say if they could see us?"
Label: mark

Text: "Say?
Label: mark

Text: Well, they'd just die to be here--hey, Hucky!"
Label: mark

Text: "I reckon so," said Huckleberry; "anyways, I'm suited.
Label: mark

Text:
I don't want
nothing better'n this.
Label: mark

Text:
I don't ever get enough to eat, gen'ally--and
here they can't come and pick at a feller and bullyrag him so."
Label: mark

Text: "It's just the life for me," said Tom.
Label: mark

Text:
"You don't have to get up,
mornings, and you don't have to go to school, and wash, and all that
blame foolishness.
Label: mark

Text:
You see a pirate don't have to do ANYTHING, Joe,
when he's ashore, but a hermit HE has to be praying considerable, and
then he don't have any fun, anyway, all by himself that way."
Label: mark

Text:
"Oh yes, that's so," said Joe, "but I hadn't thought much about it,
you know.
Label: mark

Text: I'd a good deal rather be a pirate, now that I've tried it."
Label: mark

Text:
"You see," said Tom, "people don't go much on hermits, nowadays, like
they used to in old times, but a pirate's always respected.
Label: mark

Text:
And a
hermit's got to sleep on the hardest place he can find, and put
sackcloth and ashes on his head, and stand out in the rain, and--"

"What does he put sackcloth and ashes on his head for?"
Label: mark

Text: inquired Huck.
Label: mark

Text: "I dono.
Label: mark

Text: But they've GOT to do it.
Label: mark

Text: Hermits always do.
Label: mark

Text:
You'd have to do
that if you was a hermit."
Label: mark

Text: "Dern'd if I would," said Huck.
Label: mark

Text: "Well, what would you do?"
Label: mark

Text: "I dono.
Label: mark

Text: But I wouldn't do that."
Label: mark

Text: "Why, Huck, you'd HAVE to.
Label: mark

Text: How'd you get around it?"
Label: mark

Text: "Why, I just wouldn't stand it.
Label: mark

Text: I'd run away."
Label: mark

Text: "Run away!
Label: mark

Text: Well, you WOULD be a nice old slouch of a hermit.
Label: mark

Text:
You'd be
a disgrace."
Label: mark

Text: The Red-Handed made no response, being better employed.
Label: mark

Text:
He had
finished gouging out a cob, and now he fitted a weed stem to it, loaded
it with tobacco, and was pressing a coal to the charge and blowing a
cloud of fragrant smoke--he was in the full bloom of luxurious
contentment.
Label: mark

Text:
The other pirates envied him this majestic vice, and
secretly resolved to acquire it shortly.
Label: mark

Text:
Presently Huck said:

"What does pirates have to do?"
Label: mark

Text:
Tom said:

"Oh, they have just a bully time--take ships and burn them, and get
the money and bury it in awful places in their island where there's
ghosts and things to watch it, and kill everybody in the ships--make
'em walk a plank."
Label: mark

Text:
"And they carry the women to the island," said Joe; "they don't kill
the women."
Label: mark

Text: "No," assented Tom, "they don't kill the women--they're too noble.
Label: mark

Text:
And
the women's always beautiful, too.
Label: mark

Text: "And don't they wear the bulliest clothes!
Label: mark

Text: Oh no!
Label: mark

Text:
All gold and silver
and di'monds," said Joe, with enthusiasm.
Label: mark

Text: "Who?"
Label: mark

Text: said Huck.
Label: mark

Text: "Why, the pirates."
Label: mark

Text: Huck scanned his own clothing forlornly.
Label: mark

Text:
"I reckon I ain't dressed fitten for a pirate," said he, with a
regretful pathos in his voice; "but I ain't got none but these."
Label: mark

Text:
But the other boys told him the fine clothes would come fast enough,
after they should have begun their adventures.
Label: mark

Text:
They made him understand
that his poor rags would do to begin with, though it was customary for
wealthy pirates to start with a proper wardrobe.
Label: mark

Text:
Gradually their talk died out and drowsiness began to steal upon the
eyelids of the little waifs.
Label: mark

Text:
The pipe dropped from the fingers of the
Red-Handed, and he slept the sleep of the conscience-free and the
weary.
Label: mark

Text:
The Terror of the Seas and the Black Avenger of the Spanish Main
had more difficulty in getting to sleep.
Label: mark

Text:
They said their prayers
inwardly, and lying down, since there was nobody there with authority
to make them kneel and recite aloud; in truth, they had a mind not to
say them at all, but they were afraid to proceed to such lengths as
that, lest they might call down a sudden and special thunderbolt from
heaven.
Label: mark

Text:
Then at once they reached and hovered upon the imminent verge
of sleep--but an intruder came, now, that would not "down."
Label: mark

Text:
It was
conscience.
Label: mark

Text:
They began to feel a vague fear that they had been doing
wrong to run away; and next they thought of the stolen meat, and then
the real torture came.
Label: mark

Text:
They tried to argue it away by reminding
conscience that they had purloined sweetmeats and apples scores of
times; but conscience was not to be appeased by such thin
plausibilities; it seemed to them, in the end, that there was no
getting around the stubborn fact that taking sweetmeats was only
"hooking," while taking bacon and hams and such valuables was plain
simple stealing--and there was a command against that in the Bible.
Label: mark

Text:
So
they inwardly resolved that so long as they remained in the business,
their piracies should not again be sullied with the crime of stealing.
Label: mark

Text:
Then conscience granted a truce, and these curiously inconsistent
pirates fell peacefully to sleep.
Label: mark

Text:
CHAPTER XIV

WHEN Tom awoke in the morning, he wondered where he was.
Label: mark

Text:
He sat up and
rubbed his eyes and looked around.
Label: mark

Text: Then he comprehended.
Label: mark

Text:
It was the
cool gray dawn, and there was a delicious sense of repose and peace in
the deep pervading calm and silence of the woods.
Label: mark

Text:
Not a leaf stirred;
not a sound obtruded upon great Nature's meditation.
Label: mark

Text:
Beaded dewdrops
stood upon the leaves and grasses.
Label: mark

Text:
A white layer of ashes covered the
fire, and a thin blue breath of smoke rose straight into the air.
Label: mark

Text:
Joe
and Huck still slept.
Label: mark

Text:
Now, far away in the woods a bird called; another answered; presently
the hammering of a woodpecker was heard.
Label: mark

Text:
Gradually the cool dim gray of
the morning whitened, and as gradually sounds multiplied and life
manifested itself.
Label: mark

Text:
The marvel of Nature shaking off sleep and going to
work unfolded itself to the musing boy.
Label: mark

Text:
A little green worm came
crawling over a dewy leaf, lifting two-thirds of his body into the air
from time to time and "sniffing around," then proceeding again--for he
was measuring, Tom said; and when the worm approached him, of its own
accord, he sat as still as a stone, with his hopes rising and falling,
by turns, as the creature still came toward him or seemed inclined to
go elsewhere; and when at last it considered a painful moment with its
curved body in the air and then came decisively down upon Tom's leg and
began a journey over him, his whole heart was glad--for that meant that
he was going to have a new suit of clothes--without the shadow of a
doubt a gaudy piratical uniform.
Label: mark

Text:
Now a procession of ants appeared,
from nowhere in particular, and went about their labors; one struggled
manfully by with a dead spider five times as big as itself in its arms,
and lugged it straight up a tree-trunk.
Label: mark

Text:
A brown spotted lady-bug
climbed the dizzy height of a grass blade, and Tom bent down close to
it and said, "Lady-bug, lady-bug, fly away home, your house is on fire,
your children's alone," and she took wing and went off to see about it
--which did not surprise the boy, for he knew of old that this insect was
credulous about conflagrations, and he had practised upon its
simplicity more than once.
Label: mark

Text:
A tumblebug came next, heaving sturdily at
its ball, and Tom touched the creature, to see it shut its legs against
its body and pretend to be dead.
Label: mark

Text:
The birds were fairly rioting by this
time.
Label: mark

Text:
A catbird, the Northern mocker, lit in a tree over Tom's head,
and trilled out her imitations of her neighbors in a rapture of
enjoyment; then a shrill jay swept down, a flash of blue flame, and
stopped on a twig almost within the boy's reach, cocked his head to one
side and eyed the strangers with a consuming curiosity; a gray squirrel
and a big fellow of the "fox" kind came skurrying along, sitting up at
intervals to inspect and chatter at the boys, for the wild things had
probably never seen a human being before and scarcely knew whether to
be afraid or not.
Label: mark

Text:
All Nature was wide awake and stirring, now; long
lances of sunlight pierced down through the dense foliage far and near,
and a few butterflies came fluttering upon the scene.
Label: mark

Text:
Tom stirred up the other pirates and they all clattered away with a
shout, and in a minute or two were stripped and chasing after and
tumbling over each other in the shallow limpid water of the white
sandbar.
Label: mark

Text:
They felt no longing for the little village sleeping in the
distance beyond the majestic waste of water.
Label: mark

Text:
A vagrant current or a
slight rise in the river had carried off their raft, but this only
gratified them, since its going was something like burning the bridge
between them and civilization.
Label: mark

Text:
They came back to camp wonderfully refreshed, glad-hearted, and
ravenous; and they soon had the camp-fire blazing up again.
Label: mark

Text:
Huck found
a spring of clear cold water close by, and the boys made cups of broad
oak or hickory leaves, and felt that water, sweetened with such a
wildwood charm as that, would be a good enough substitute for coffee.
Label: mark

Text:
While Joe was slicing bacon for breakfast, Tom and Huck asked him to
hold on a minute; they stepped to a promising nook in the river-bank
and threw in their lines; almost immediately they had reward.
Label: mark

Text:
Joe had
not had time to get impatient before they were back again with some
handsome bass, a couple of sun-perch and a small catfish--provisions
enough for quite a family.
Label: mark

Text:
They fried the fish with the bacon, and were
astonished; for no fish had ever seemed so delicious before.
Label: mark

Text:
They did
not know that the quicker a fresh-water fish is on the fire after he is
caught the better he is; and they reflected little upon what a sauce
open-air sleeping, open-air exercise, bathing, and a large ingredient
of hunger make, too.
Label: mark

Text:
They lay around in the shade, after breakfast, while Huck had a smoke,
and then went off through the woods on an exploring expedition.
Label: mark

Text:
They
tramped gayly along, over decaying logs, through tangled underbrush,
among solemn monarchs of the forest, hung from their crowns to the

boom came floating down out of the distance.

Text:
A person who is ignorant of legal matters is always liable to make
mistakes when he tries to photograph a court scene with his pen; and so
I was not willing to let the law chapters in this book go to press
without first subjecting them to rigid and exhausting revision and
correction by a trained barrister--if that is what they are called.
Label: mark

Text:
These chapters are right, now, in every detail, for they were rewritten
under the immediate eye of William Hicks, who studied law part of a
while in southwest Missouri thirty-five years ago and then came over
here to Florence for his health and is still helping for exercise and
board in Macaroni Vermicelli's horse-feed shed which is up the back
alley as you turn around the corner out of the Piazza del Duomo just
beyond the house where that stone that Dante used to sit on six hundred
years ago is let into the wall when he let on to be watching them build
Giotto's campanile and yet always got tired looking as soon as Beatrice
passed along on her way to get a chunk of chestnut cake to defend
herself with in case of a Ghibelline outbreak before she got to school,
at the same old stand where they sell the same old cake to this day and
it is just as light and good as it was then, too, and this is not
flattery, far from it.

straight, now.

Text:
Given under my hand this second day of January, 1893, at the Villa
Viviani, village of Settignano, three miles back of Florence, on the
hills--the same certainly affording the most charming view to be found
on this planet, and with it the most dreamlike and enchanting sunsets to
be found in any planet or even in any solar system--and given, too, in
the swell room of the house, with the busts of Cerretani senators and
other grandees of this line looking approvingly down upon me as they
used to look down upon Dante, and mutely asking me to adopt them into my
family, which I do with pleasure, for my remotest ancestors are but
spring chickens compared with these robed and stately antiques, and it
will be a great and satisfying lift for me, that six hundred years will.

CHAPTER I.

Pudd'nhead Wins His Name.

Text:

Text:
The scene of this chronicle is the town of Dawson's Landing, on the
Missouri side of the Mississippi, half a day's journey, per steamboat,
below St. Louis.
Label: mark

Text:
In 1830 it was a snug little collection of modest one- and two-story
frame dwellings whose whitewashed exteriors were almost concealed from
sight by climbing tangles of rose-vines, honeysuckles, and
morning-glories.
Label: mark

Text:
Each of these pretty homes had a garden in front fenced
with white palings and opulently stocked with hollyhocks, marigolds,
touch-me-nots, prince's-feathers and other old-fashioned flowers; while
on the window-sills of the houses stood wooden boxes containing
moss-rose plants and terra-cotta pots in which grew a breed of geranium
whose spread of intensely red blossoms accented the prevailing pink tint
of the rose-clad house-front like an explosion of flame.
Label: mark

Text:
When there was
room on the ledge outside of the pots and boxes for a cat, the cat was
there--in sunny weather--stretched at full length, asleep and blissful,
with her furry belly to the sun and a paw curved over her nose.
Label: mark

Text:
Then
that house was complete, and its contentment and peace were made
manifest to the world by this symbol, whose testimony is infallible.
Label: mark

Text:
A
home without a cat--and a well-fed, well-petted and properly revered
cat--may be a perfect home, perhaps, but how can it prove title?
Label: mark

Text:
All along the streets, on both sides, at the outer edge of the brick
sidewalks, stood locust-trees with trunks protected by wooden boxing,
and these furnished shade for summer and a sweet fragrance in spring
when the clusters of buds came forth.
Label: mark

Text:
The main street, one block back
from the river, and running parallel with it, was the sole business
street.
Label: mark

Text:
It was six blocks long, and in each block two or three brick
stores three stories high towered above interjected bunches of little
frame shops.
Label: mark

Text:
Swinging signs creaked in the wind, the street's whole
length.
Label: mark

Text:
The candy-striped pole which indicates nobility proud and
ancient along the palace-bordered canals of Venice, indicated merely the
humble barber shop along the main street of Dawson's Landing.
Label: mark

Text:
On a chief
corner stood a lofty unpainted pole wreathed from top to bottom with tin
pots and pans and cups, the chief tinmonger's noisy notice to the world
(when the wind blew) that his shop was on hand for business at that
corner.
Label: mark

Text:
The hamlet's front was washed by the clear waters of the great river;
its body stretched itself rearward up a gentle incline; its most
rearward border fringed itself out and scattered its houses about the
base-line of the hills; the hills rose high, inclosing the town in a
half-moon curve, clothed with forests from foot to summit.
Label: mark

Text: Steamboats passed up and down every hour or so.
Label: mark

Text:
Those belonging to the
little Cairo line and the little Memphis line always stopped; the big
Orleans liners stopped for hails only, or to land passengers or freight;
and this was the case also with the great flotilla of "transients."
Label: mark

Text:
These latter came out of a dozen rivers--the Illinois, the Missouri, the
Upper Mississippi, the Ohio, the Monongahela, the Tennessee, the Red
River, the White River, and so on; and were bound every whither and
stocked with every imaginable comfort or necessity which the
Mississippi's communities could want, from the frosty Falls of St.
Anthony down through nine climates to torrid New Orleans.
Label: mark

Text:
Dawson's Landing was a slaveholding town, with a rich slave-worked grain
and pork country back of it.
Label: mark

Text:
The town was sleepy and comfortable and
contented.
Label: mark

Text:
It was fifty years old, and was growing slowly--very slowly,
in fact, but still it was growing.
Label: mark

Text:
The chief citizen was York Leicester Driscoll, about forty years old,
judge of the county court.
Label: mark

Text:
He was very proud of his old Virginian
ancestry, and in his hospitalities and his rather formal and stately
manners he kept up its traditions.
Label: mark

Text: He was fine and just and generous.
Label: mark

Text:
To
be a gentleman--a gentleman without stain or blemish--was his only
religion, and to it he was always faithful.
Label: mark

Text:
He was respected, esteemed
and beloved by all the community.
Label: mark

Text:
He was well off, and was gradually
adding to his store.
Label: mark

Text:
He and his wife were very nearly happy, but not
quite, for they had no children.
Label: mark

Text:
The longing for the treasure of a child
had grown stronger and stronger as the years slipped away, but the
blessing never came--and was never to come.
Label: mark

Text:
With this pair lived the Judge's widowed sister, Mrs. Rachel Pratt, and
she also was childless--childless, and sorrowful for that reason, and
not to be comforted.
Label: mark

Text:
The women were good and commonplace people, and did
their duty and had their reward in clear consciences and the community's
approbation.
Label: mark

Text: They were Presbyterians, the Judge was a free-thinker.
Label: mark

Text:
Pembroke Howard, lawyer and bachelor, aged about forty, was another old
Virginian grandee with proved descent from the First Families.
Label: mark

Text:
He was a
fine, brave, majestic creature, a gentleman according to the nicest
requirements of the Virginia rule, a devoted Presbyterian, an authority
on the "code," and a man always courteously ready to stand up before you
in the field if any act or word of his had seemed doubtful or suspicious
to you, and explain it with any weapon you might prefer from brad-awls
to artillery.
Label: mark

Text:
He was very popular with the people, and was the Judge's
dearest friend.
Label: mark

Text:
Then there was Colonel Cecil Burleigh Essex, another F. F. V. of
formidable caliber--however, with him we have no concern.
Label: mark

Text:
Percy Northumberland Driscoll, brother to the Judge, and younger than he
by five years, was a married man, and had had children around his
hearthstone; but they were attacked in detail by measles, croup and
scarlet fever, and this had given the doctor a chance with his effective
antediluvian methods; so the cradles were empty.
Label: mark

Text:
He was a prosperous
man, with a good head for speculations, and his fortune was growing.
Label: mark

Text:
On
the 1st of February, 1830, two boy babes were born in his house: one to
him, the other to one of his slave girls, Roxana by name.
Label: mark

Text:
Roxana was
twenty years old.
Label: mark

Text:
She was up and around the same day, with her hands
full, for she was tending both babies.
Label: mark

Text: Mrs. Percy Driscoll died within the week.
Label: mark

Text:
Roxy remained in charge of the
children.
Label: mark

Text:
She had her own way, for Mr. Driscoll soon absorbed himself in
his speculations and left her to her own devices.
Label: mark

Text: This was Mr. David Wilson, a young fellow of Scotch parentage.
Label: mark

Label: mark

He was a homely, freckled, sandy-haired young fellow, with an

But for an unfortunate remark of his,

Pudd'nhead Wilson had a trifle of money when he arrived, and he bought a

Text:

DAVID WILSON.

Text: SURVEYING, CONVEYANCING, ETC.

Label: mark

Text:
No
clients came.
Label: mark

Text:
He took down his sign, after a while, and put it up on his

Label: mark

Text:
It offered his
services now in the humble capacities of land-surveyor and expert
accountant.
Label: mark

Text:
Now and then he got a job of surveying to do, and now and

Label: mark

Text:
With Scotch
patience and pluck he resolved to live down his reputation and work his
way into the legal field yet.
Label: mark

Text:
Poor fellow, he could not foresee that it

Label: mark

Text:
He had a rich abundance of idle time, but it never hung heavy on his

Label: mark

Text: One of his pet fads was palmistry.
Label: mark

Text:
To another one he gave no
name, neither would he explain to anybody what its purpose was, but

Label: mark

Text:
In fact he had found that his fads

Label: mark

Text:
The fad without a name was one
which dealt with people's finger-marks.
Label: mark

Text:
He carried in his coat pocket a
shallow box with grooves in it, and in the grooves strips of glass five

Label: mark

Text:
Along the lower edge of each strip
was pasted a slip of white paper.
Label: mark

Text:
He asked people to pass their hands
through their hair (thus collecting upon them a thin coating of the

Text:
Under this row

John Smith, right hand--

and add the day of the month and the year, then take Smith's left hand

Label: mark

Text:

Label: mark

Text:
He often studied his records, examining and poring over them with

he found anything--he revealed to no one.
Label: mark

Text:
Sometimes he copied on paper

The next day--that is to say, on the 4th of September--something
occurred which profoundly impressed Roxana.
Label: mark

Text:
Mr. Driscoll missed another
small sum of money--which is a way of saying that this was not a new
thing, but had happened before.
Label: mark

Text:
In truth it had happened three times
before.
Label: mark

Text: Driscoll's patience was exhausted.
Label: mark

Text:
He was a fairly humane man
toward slaves and other animals; he was an exceedingly humane man toward
the erring of his own race.
Label: mark

Text:
Theft he could not abide, and plainly there
was a thief in his house.
Label: mark

Text:
Necessarily the thief must be one of his
negroes.
Label: mark

Text: Sharp measures must be taken.
Label: mark

Text:
He called his servants before
him.
Label: mark

Text:
There were three of these, besides Roxy: a man, a woman, and a boy
twelve years old.
Label: mark

Text: They were not related.
Label: mark

Text:
Mr. Driscoll said:

"You have all been warned before.
Label: mark

Text: It has done no good.
Label: mark

Text:
This time I will
teach you a lesson.
Label: mark

Text: I will sell the thief.
Label: mark

Text:
Which of you is the guilty
one?"
Label: mark

Text:
They all shuddered at the threat, for here they had a good home, and a
new one was likely to be a change for the worse.
Label: mark

Text: The denial was general.
Label: mark

Text:
None had stolen anything--not money, anyway--a little sugar, or cake, or
honey, or something like that, that "Marse Percy wouldn't mind or miss,"
but not money--never a cent of money.
Label: mark

Text:
They were eloquent in their
protestations, but Mr. Driscoll was not moved by them.
Label: mark

Text:
He answered each
in turn with a stern "Name the thief!"
Label: mark

Text:
The truth was, all were guilty but Roxana; she suspected that the others
were guilty, but she did not know them to be so.
Label: mark

Text:
She was horrified to
think how near she had come to being guilty herself; she had been saved
in the nick of time by a revival in the colored Methodist Church, a
fortnight before, at which time and place she "got religion."
Label: mark

Text:
The very
next day after that gracious experience, while her change of style was
fresh upon her and she was vain of her purified condition, her master
left a couple dollars lying unprotected on his desk, and she happened
upon that temptation when she was polishing around with a dust-rag.
Label: mark

Text:
She
looked at the money awhile with a steady rising resentment, then she
burst out with--

"Dad blame dat revival, I wisht it had 'a' be'n put off till to-morrow!"
Label: mark

To day in our yong Lords: but they may iest
Till their owne scorne returne to them vnnoted
Ere they can hide their leuitie in honour:
So like a Courtier, contempt nor bitternesse
Were in his pride, or sharpnesse; if they were,
His equall had awak'd them, and his honour
Clocke to it selfe, knew the true minute when
Exception bid him speake: and at this time
His tongue obey'd his hand.

On the Catastrophe and heele of pastime
When it was out: Let me not liue (quoth hee)
After my flame lackes oyle, to be the snuffe

Promis’d no less to them?
Label: william

Text: BANQUO.
Label: william

Text:
That, trusted home,
Might yet enkindle you unto the crown,
Besides the Thane of Cawdor.
Label: william

Text:
But ’tis strange:
And oftentimes to win us to our harm,
The instruments of darkness tell us truths;
Win us with honest trifles, to betray’s
In deepest consequence.—
Cousins, a word, I pray you.
Label: william

Text: MACBETH.
Label: william

Text:
[_Aside._] Two truths are told,
As happy prologues to the swelling act
Of the imperial theme.—I thank you, gentlemen.—
[_Aside._] This supernatural soliciting
Cannot be ill; cannot be good.
Label: william

Text:
If ill,
Why hath it given me earnest of success,
Commencing in a truth?
Label: william

Text:
﻿ACT I

SCENE I. Windsor.
Label: william

Text:
Before Page’s house


Enter Justice Shallow, Slender and Sir Hugh Evans.
Label: william

Text: SHALLOW.
Label: william

Text: Sir Hugh, persuade me not.
Label: william

Text: I will make a Star Chamber matter of it.
Label: william

Text:
If
he were twenty Sir John Falstaffs, he shall not abuse Robert Shallow,
esquire.
Label: william

Text: SLENDER.
Label: william

Text: In the county of Gloucester, Justice of Peace and Coram.
Label: william

Text: SHALLOW.
Label: william

Text: Ay, cousin Slender, and Custalorum.
Label: william

Text: SLENDER.
Label: william

Text:
Ay, and Ratolorum too; and a gentleman born, Master Parson, who writes
himself “Armigero” in any bill, warrant, quittance, or
obligation—“Armigero.”

SHALLOW.
Label: william

Text: Ay, that I do, and have done any time these three hundred years.
Label: william

Text: SLENDER.
Label: william

Text:
All his successors, gone before him hath done’t; and all his ancestors
that come after him may.
Label: william

Text:
They may give the dozen white luces in their
coat.
Label: william

Text: SHALLOW.
Label: william

Text: It is an old coat.
Label: william

Text: EVANS.
Label: william

Text: The dozen white louses do become an old coat well.
Label: william

Text:
It agrees well,
passant.
Label: william

Text: It is a familiar beast to man, and signifies love.
Label: william

Text: SHALLOW.
Label: william

Text: The luce is the fresh fish.
Label: william

Text: The salt fish is an old coat.
Label: william

Text: SLENDER.
Label: william

Text: I may quarter, coz.
Label: william

Text: SHALLOW.
Label: william

Text: You may, by marrying.
Label: william

Text: EVANS.
Label: william

Text: It is marring indeed, if he quarter it.
Label: william

Text: SHALLOW.
Label: william

Text: Not a whit.
Label: william

Text: EVANS.
Label: william

Text: Yes, py’r Lady.
Label: william

Text:
If he has a quarter of your coat, there is but three
skirts for yourself, in my simple conjectures.
Label: william

Text: But that is all one.
Label: william

Text:
If
Sir John Falstaff have committed disparagements unto you, I am of the
Church, and will be glad to do my benevolence to make atonements and
compremises between you.
Label: william

Text: SHALLOW.
Label: william

Text: The Council shall hear it; it is a riot.
Label: william

Text: EVANS.
Label: william

Text: It is not meet the Council hear a riot.
Label: william

Text:
There is no fear of Got in a
riot.
Label: william

Text:
The Council, look you, shall desire to hear the fear of Got, and
not to hear a riot.
Label: william

Text: Take your vizaments in that.
Label: william

Text: SHALLOW.
Label: william

Text: Ha!
Label: william

Text: O’ my life, if I were young again, the sword should end it.
Label: william

Text: EVANS.
Label: william

Text:
It is petter that friends is the sword, and end it; and there is also
another device in my prain, which peradventure prings goot discretions
with it.
Label: william

Text:
There is Anne Page, which is daughter to Master George Page,
which is pretty virginity.
Label: william

Text: SLENDER.
Label: william

Text: Mistress Anne Page?
Label: william

Text: She has brown hair, and speaks small like a woman?
Label: william

Text: EVANS.
Label: william

Text:
It is that fery person for all the ’orld, as just as you will desire,
and seven hundred pounds of moneys, and gold, and silver, is her
grandsire upon his death’s-bed—Got deliver to a joyful
resurrections!—give, when she is able to overtake seventeen years old.
Label: william

Text:
It were a goot motion if we leave our pribbles and prabbles, and desire
a marriage between Master Abraham and Mistress Anne Page.
Label: william

Text: SHALLOW.
Label: william

Text: Did her grandsire leave her seven hundred pound?
Label: william

Text: EVANS.
Label: william

Text: Ay, and her father is make her a petter penny.
Label: william

Text: SHALLOW.
Label: william

Text: I know the young gentlewoman; she has good gifts.
Label: william

Text: EVANS.
Label: william

Text: Seven hundred pounds, and possibilities, is goot gifts.
Label: william

Text: SHALLOW.
Label: william

Text: Well, let us see honest Master Page.
Label: william

Text: Is Falstaff there?
Label: william

Text: EVANS.
Label: william

Text: Shall I tell you a lie?
Label: william

Text:
I do despise a liar as I do despise one that is
false, or as I despise one that is not true.
Label: william

Text:
The knight Sir John is
there, and I beseech you be ruled by your well-willers.
Label: william

Text:
I will peat the
door for Master Page.
Label: william

Text:
[_Knocks._]

What, ho!
Label: william

Text: Got pless your house here!
Label: william

Text: PAGE.
Label: william

Text: [_Within_.]
Label: william

Text: Who’s there?
Label: william

Text: EVANS.
Label: william

Text:
Here is Got’s plessing, and your friend, and Justice Shallow, and here
young Master Slender, that peradventures shall tell you another tale,
if matters grow to your likings.
Label: william

Text: Enter Page.
Label: william

Text: PAGE.
Label: william

Text: I am glad to see your worships well.
Label: william

Text:
I thank you for my venison, Master
Shallow.
Label: william

Text: SHALLOW.
Label: william

Text: Master Page, I am glad to see you, much good do it your good heart!
Label: william

Text:
I
wished your venison better; it was ill killed.
Label: william

Text:
How doth good Mistress
Page?
Label: william

Text: And I thank you always with my heart, la, with my heart.
Label: william

Text: PAGE.
Label: william

Text: Sir, I thank you.
Label: william

Text: SHALLOW.
Label: william

Text: Sir, I thank you; by yea and no, I do.
Label: william

Text: PAGE.
Label: william

Text: I am glad to see you, good Master Slender.
Label: william

Text: SLENDER.
Label: william

Text: How does your fallow greyhound, sir?
Label: william

Text:
I heard say he was outrun on
Cotsall.
Label: william

Text: PAGE.
Label: william

Text: It could not be judged, sir.
Label: william

Text: SLENDER.
Label: william

Text: You’ll not confess, you’ll not confess.
Label: william

Text: SHALLOW.
Label: william

Text: That he will not.
Label: william

Text: ’Tis your fault; ’tis your fault.
Label: william

Text: ’Tis a good dog.
Label: william

Text: PAGE.
Label: william

Text: A cur, sir.
Label: william

Text: SHALLOW.
Label: william

Text: Sir, he’s a good dog, and a fair dog, can there be more said?
Label: william

Text:
He is
good, and fair.
Label: william

Text: Is Sir John Falstaff here?
Label: william

Text: PAGE.
Label: william

Text: Sir, he is within; and I would I could do a good office between you.
Label: william

Text: EVANS.
Label: william

Text: It is spoke as a Christians ought to speak.
Label: william

Text: SHALLOW.
Label: william

Text: He hath wronged me, Master Page.
Label: william

Text: PAGE.
Label: william

Text: Sir, he doth in some sort confess it.
Label: william

Text: SHALLOW.
Label: william

Text: If it be confessed, it is not redressed.
Label: william

Text: Is not that so, Master Page?
Label: william

Text: He hath wronged me, indeed he hath, at a word, he hath.
Label: william

Text: Believe me.
Label: william

Text: Robert Shallow, esquire, saith he is wronged.
Label: william

Text: PAGE.
Label: william

Text: Here comes Sir John.
Label: william

Label: william

Text: FALSTAFF.
Label: william

Text: Now, Master Shallow, you’ll complain of me to the King?
Label: william

Text: SHALLOW.
Label: william

Text:
Knight, you have beaten my men, killed my deer, and broke open my
lodge.
Label: william

Text: FALSTAFF.
Label: william

Text: But not kissed your keeper’s daughter!
Label: william

Text: SHALLOW.
Label: william

Text: Tut, a pin!
Label: william

Text: This shall be answered.
Label: william

Text: FALSTAFF.
Label: william

Text: I will answer it straight: I have done all this.
Label: william

Text: That is now answered.
Label: william

Text: SHALLOW.
Label: william

Text: The Council shall know this.
Label: william

Text: FALSTAFF.
Label: william

Text:
’Twere better for you if it were known in counsel: you’ll be laughed
at.
Label: william

Text: EVANS.
Label: william

Text: _Pauca verba_, Sir John; goot worts.
Label: william

Text: FALSTAFF.
Label: william

Text: Good worts?
Label: william

Text: Good cabbage!—Slender, I broke your head.
Label: william

Text:
What matter have
you against me?
Label: william

Text: SLENDER.
Label: william

Text:
Marry, sir, I have matter in my head against you, and against your
cony-catching rascals, Bardolph, Nym, and Pistol.
Label: william

Text:
They carried me to
the tavern and made me drunk, and afterwards picked my pocket.
Label: william

Text: BARDOLPH.
Label: william

Text: You Banbury cheese!
Label: william

Text: SLENDER.
Label: william

Text: Ay, it is no matter.
Label: william

Text: PISTOL.
Label: william

Text: How now, Mephostophilus?
Label: william

Text: SLENDER.
Label: william

Text: Ay, it is no matter.
Label: william

Text: NYM.
Label: william

Text: Slice, I say!
Label: william

Text: _Pauca, pauca_, slice, that’s my humour.
Label: william

Text: SLENDER.
Label: william

Text: Where’s Simple, my man?
Label: william

Text: Can you tell, cousin?
Label: william

Text: EVANS.
Label: william

Text: Peace, I pray you.
Label: william

Text:
Now let us understand; there is three umpires in
this matter, as I understand: that is, Master Page, _fidelicet_ Master
Page; and there is myself, _fidelicet_ myself; and the three party is,
lastly and finally, mine host of the Garter.
Label: william

Text: PAGE.
Label: william

Text: We three to hear it and end it between them.
Label: william

Text: EVANS.
Label: william

Text: Fery goot.
Label: william

Text:
I will make a prief of it in my notebook, and we will
afterwards ’ork upon the cause with as great discreetly as we can.
Label: william

Text: FALSTAFF.
Label: william

Text: Pistol!
Label: william

Text: PISTOL.
Label: william

Text: He hears with ears.
Label: william

Text: EVANS.
Label: william

Text: The tevil and his tam!
Label: william

Text: What phrase is this, “He hears with ear”?
Label: william

Text:
Why,
it is affectations.
Label: william

Text: FALSTAFF.
Label: william

Text: Pistol, did you pick Master Slender’s purse?
Label: william

Text: SLENDER.
Label: william

Text:
Ay, by these gloves, did he, or I would I might never come in mine own
great chamber again else!
Label: william

Text:
Of seven groats in mill-sixpences, and two
Edward shovel-boards that cost me two shilling and two pence a-piece of
Yed Miller, by these gloves.
Label: william

Text: FALSTAFF.
Label: william

Text: Is this true, Pistol?
Label: william

Text: EVANS.
Label: william

Text: No, it is false, if it is a pick-purse.
Label: william

Text: PISTOL.
Label: william

Text:
Ha, thou mountain-foreigner!—Sir John and master mine,
I combat challenge of this latten bilbo.—
Word of denial in thy _labras_ here!
Label: william

Text: Word of denial!
Label: william

Text: Froth and scum, thou liest.
Label: william

Text: SLENDER.
Label: william

Text: [_Points at Nym_.]
Label: william

Text: By these gloves, then, ’twas he.
Label: william
